VOLUME I A BACKWARD LOOK As I sat smoking, alone, yesterday, And lazily leaning back in my chair, Enjoying myself in a general wayâ Allowing my thoughts a holiday From weariness, toil and care,â My fanciesâdoubtless, for ventilationâ Left ajar the gates of my mind,â And Memory, seeing the situation, Slipped out in the street of âAuld Lang Syne.ââ Wandering ever with tireless feet Through scenes of silence, and jubilee Of long-hushed voices; and faces sweet Were thronging the shadowy side of the street As far as the eye could see; Dreaming again, in anticipation, The same old dreams of our boyhood's days That never come true, from the vague sensation Of walking asleep in the world's strange ways. Away to the house where I was born! And there was the selfsame clock that ticked From the close of dusk to the burst of morn, When life-warm hands plucked the golden corn And helped when the apples were picked. And the âchany dogâ on the mantel-shelf, With the gilded collar and yellow eyes, Looked just as at first, when I hugged myself Sound asleep with the dear surprise. And down to the swing in the locust-tree, Where the grass was worn from the trampled ground, And where âEckâ Skinner, âOldâ Carr, and three Or four such other boys used to be âDoin' sky-scrapers,â or âwhirlin' roundâ: And again Bob climbed for the bluebird's nest, And again âhad showsâ in the buggy-shed Of Guymon's barn, where still, unguessed, The old ghosts romp through the best days dead! And again I gazed from the old schoolroom With a wistful look, of a long June day, When on my cheek was the hectic bloom Caught of Mischief, as I presumeâ He had such a âpartialâ way, It seemed, toward me.âAnd again I thought Of a probable likelihood to be Kept in after schoolâfor a girl was caught Catching a note from me. And down through the woods to the swimming-holeâ Where the big, white, hollow old sycamore grows,â And we never cared when the water was cold, And always âduckedâ the boy that told On the fellow that tied the clothes.â When life went so like a dreamy rhyme, That it seems to me now that then The world was having a jollier time Than it ever will have again. PHILIPER FLASH Young Philiper Flash was a promising lad, His intentions were goodâbut oh, how sad For a person to think How the veriest pink And bloom of perfection may turn out bad. Old Flash himself was a moral man, And prided himself on a moral plan, Of a maxim as old As the calf of gold, Of making that boy do what he was told. And such a good mother had Philiper Flash; Her voice was as soft as the creamy plash Of the milky wave With its musical lave That gushed through the holes of her patent churn-dash;â And the excellent woman loved Philiper so, She could cry sometimes when he stumped his toe,â And she stroked his hair With such motherly care When the dear little angel learned to swear. Old Flash himself would sometimes say That his wife had âsuch a ridiculous way,â She'd humor that child Till he'd soon be sp'iled, And then there'd be the devil to pay!â And the excellent wife, with a martyr's look, Would tell old Flash himself âhe took No notice at all Of the bright-eyed doll Unless when he spanked him for getting a fall!â Young Philiper Flash, as time passed by, Grew into âa boy with a roguish eyeâ: He could smoke a cigar, And seemed by far The most promising youth.ââHe's powerful sly,â Old Flash himself once told a friend, âEvery copper he gets he's sure to spendâ And,â said he, âdon't you know If he keeps on so What a crop of wild oats the boy will grow!â But his dear good mother knew Philiper's ways Soâwell, she managed the money to raise; And old Flash himself Was âlaid on the shelf,â (In the manner of speaking we have nowadays). For âgracious knows, her darling child, If he went without money he'd soon grow wild.â So Philiper Flash With a regular dash âSwung on to the reins,â and went âslingin' the cash.â As old Flash himself, in his office one day, Was shaving notes in a barberous way, At the hour of four Death entered the door And shaved the note on his life, they say. And he had for his grave a magnificent tomb, Though the venturous finger that pointed âGone Home,â Looked white and cold From being so bold, As it feared that a popular lie was told. Young Philiper Flash was a man of style When he first began unpacking the pile Of the dollars and dimes Whose jingling chimes Had clinked to the tune of his father's smile; And he strewed his wealth with such lavish hand, His rakish ways were the talk of the land, And gossipers wise Sat winking their eyes (A certain foreboding of fresh surprise). A âfast young manâ was Philiper Flash, And wore âloud clothesâ and a weak mustache, And âdone the Park,â For an âafternoon lark,â With a very fast horse of âremarkable dash.â And Philiper handled a billiard-cue About as well as the best he knew, And used to say âHe could make it pay By playing two or three games a day.â And Philiper Flash was his mother's joy, He seemed to her the magic alloy That made her glad, When her heart was sad, With the thought that âshe lived for her darling boy.â His dear good mother wasn't aware How her darling boy relished a âtare.ââ She said âone night He gave her a fright By coming home late and acting tight.â Young Philiper Flash, on a winterish day, Was published a bankrupt, so they sayâ And as far as I know I suppose it was so, For matters went on in a singular way; His excellent mother, I think I was told, Died from exposure and want and cold; And Philiper Flash, With a horrible slash, Whacked his jugular open and went to smash. THE SAME OLD STORY The same old story told againâ The maiden droops her head, The ripening glow of her crimson cheek Is answering in her stead. The pleading tone of a trembling voice Is telling her the way He loved her when his heart was young In Youth's sunshiny day: The trembling tongue, the longing tone, Imploringly ask why They can not be as happy now As in the days gone by. And two more hearts, tumultuous With overflowing joy, Are dancing to the music Which that dear, provoking boy Is twanging on his bowstring, As, fluttering his wings, He sends his love-charged arrows While merrily he sings: âHo! ho! my dainty maiden, It surely can not be You are thinking you are master Of your heart, when it is me.â And another gleaming arrow Does the little god's behest, And the dainty little maiden Falls upon her lover's breast. âThe same old story told again,â And listened o'er and o'er, Will still be new, and pleasing, too, Till âTime shall be no more.â TO A BOY WHISTLING The smiling face of a happy boy With its enchanted key Is now unlocking in memory My store of heartiest joy. And my lost life again to-day, In pleasant colors all aglow, From rainbow tints, to pure white snow, Is a panorama sliding away. The whistled air of a simple tune Eddies and whirls my thoughts around, As fairy balloons of thistle-down Sail through the air of June. O happy boy with untaught grace! What is there in the world to give That can buy one hour of the life you live Or the trivial cause of your smiling face! AN OLD FRIEND Hey, Old Midsummer! are you here again, With all your harvest-store of olden joys,â Vast overhanging meadow-lands of rain, And drowsy dawns, and noons when golden grain Nods in the sun, and lazy truant boys Drift ever listlessly adown the day, Too full of joy to rest, and dreams to play. The same old Summer, with the same old smile Beaming upon us in the same old way We knew in childhood! Though a weary while Since that far time, yet memories reconcile The heart with odorous breaths of clover hay; And again I hear the doves, and the sun streams through The old barn door just as it used to do. And so it seems like welcoming a friendâ An old, old friend, upon his coming home From some far countryâcoming home to spend Long, loitering days with me: And I extend My hand in rapturous glee:âAnd so you've come!â Ho, I'm so glad! Come in and take a chair: Well, this is just like old times, I declare! WHAT SMITH KNEW ABOUT FARMING There wasn't two purtier farms in the state Than the couple of which I'm about to relate;â Jinin' each otherâbelongin' to Brown, And jest at the edge of a flourishin' town. Brown was a man, as I understand, That allus had handled a good 'eal o' land, And was sharp as a tack in drivin' a tradeâ For that's the way most of his money was made. And all the grounds and the orchards about His two pet farms was all tricked out With poppies and posies And sweet-smellin' rosies; And hundreds o' kinds Of all sorts o' vines, To tickle the most horticultural minds; And little dwarf trees not as thick as your wrist With ripe apples on 'em as big as your fist: And peaches,âSiberian crabs and pears, And quincesâWell! any fruit any tree bears; And th' purtiest streamâjest a-swimmin' with fish, Andâjest o'most everything heart could wish! The purtiest orch'rdsâI wish you could see How purty they was, fer I know it 'ud be A regular treat!âbut I'll go ahead with My story! A man by the name o' Smithâ (A bad name to rhyme, But I reckon that I'm Not goin' back on a Smith! nary time!) 'At hadn't a soul of kin nor kith, And more money than he knowed what to do with,â So he comes a-ridin' along one day, And he says to Brown, in his offhand wayâ Who was trainin' some newfangled vines round a bay- WinderââHowdy-doâlook-a-hereâsay: What'll you take fer this property here?â I'm talkin' o' leavin' the city this year, And I want to be Where the air is free, And I'll buy this place, if it ain't too dear!ââ Wellâthey grumbled and jawed aroun'â âI don't like to part with the place,â says Brown; âWell,â says Smith, a-jerkin' his head, âThat house yonderâbricks painted redâ Jest like this'nâa purtier viewâ Who is it owns it?â âThat's mine too,â Says Brown, as he winked at a hole in his shoe, âBut I'll tell you right here jest what I kin do:â If you'll pay the figgers I'll sell it to you.â Smith went over and looked at the placeâ Badgered with Brown, and argied the caseâ Thought that Brown's figgers was rather too tall, But, findin' that Brown wasn't goin' to fall, In final agreed, So they drawed up the deed Fer the farm and the fixturesâthe live stock an' all. And so Smith moved from the city as soon As he possibly couldâBut âthe man in the moonâ Knowed more'n Smith o' farmin' pursuits, And jest to convince you, and have no disputes, How little he knowed, I'll tell you his âmode,â As he called it, o' raisin' âthe best that growed,â In the way o' potatoesâ Cucumbersâtomatoes, And squashes as lengthy as young alligators. 'Twas allus a curious thing to me How big a fool a feller kin be When he gits on a farm after leavin' a town!â Expectin' to raise himself up to renown, And reap fer himself agricultural fame, By growin' of squashesâwithout any shameâ As useless and long as a technical name. To make the soil pure, And certainly sure, He plastered the ground with patent manure. He had cultivators, and double-hoss plows, And patent machines fer milkin' his cows; And patent hay-forksâpatent measures and weights, And new patent back-action hinges fer gates, And barn locks and latches, and such little dribs, And patents to keep the rats out o' the cribsâ Reapers and mowers, And patent grain sowers; And drillers And tillers And cucumber hillers, And horries;âand had patent rollers and scrapers, And took about ten agricultural papers. So you can imagine how matters turned out: But Brown didn't have not a shadder o' doubt That Smith didn't know what he was about When he said that âthe old way to farm was played out.â But Smith worked ahead, And when any one said That the old way o' workin' was better instead O' his âmodern idees,â he allus turned red, And wanted to know What made people so Infernally anxious to hear theirselves crow? And guessed that he'd manage to hoe his own row. Brown he come onc't and leant over the fence, And told Smith that he couldn't see any sense In goin' to such a tremendous expense Fer the sake o' such no-account experiments:â âThat'll never make corn! As shore's you're born It'll come out the leetlest end of the horn!â Says Brown, as he pulled off a big roastin'-ear From a stalk of his own That had tribble outgrown Smith's poor yaller shoots, and says he, âLooky here! This corn was raised in the old-fashioned way, And I rather imagine that this corn'll pay Expenses fer raisin' it!âWhat do you say?â Brown got him then to look over his crop.â His luck that season had been tip-top! And you may surmise Smith opened his eyes And let out a look o' the wildest surprise When Brown showed him punkins as big as the lies He was stuffin' him withâabout offers he's had Fer his farm: âI don't want to sell very bad,â He says, but says he, âMr. Smith, you kin see Fer yourself how matters is standin' with me, I understand farmin' and I'd better stay, You know, on my farm;âI'm a-makin' it payâ I oughtn't to grumble!âI reckon I'll clear Away over four thousand dollars this year.â And that was the reason, he made it appear, Why he didn't care about sellin' his farm, And hinted at his havin' done himself harm In sellin' the other, and wanted to know If Smith wouldn't sell back ag'in to him.âSo Smith took the bait, and says he, âMr. Brown, I wouldn't sell out but we might swap aroun'â How'll you trade your place fer mine?â (Purty sharp way o' comin' the shine Over Smith! Wasn't it?) Well, sir, this Brown Played out his hand and brought Smithy downâ Traded with him an', workin' it cute, Raked in two thousand dollars to boot As slick as a whistle, an' that wasn't all,â He managed to trade back ag'in the next fall,â And the nextâand the nextâas long as Smith stayed He reaped with his harvests an annual trade.â Why, I reckon that Brown must 'a' easily madeâ On an averageânearly two thousand a yearâ Together he made over seven thousandâclear.â Till Mr. Smith found he was losin' his health In as big a proportion, almost, as his wealth; So at last he concluded to move back to town, And sold back his farm to this same Mr. Brown At very low figgers, by gittin' it down. Further'n this I have nothin' to say Than merely advisin' the Smiths fer to stay In their grocery stores in flourishin' towns And leave agriculture aloneâand the Browns. A POET'S WOOING I woo'd a woman once, But she was sharper than an eastern wind. âTennyson. âWhat may I do to make you glad, To make you glad and free, Till your light smiles glance And your bright eyes dance Like sunbeams on the sea? Read some rhyme that is blithe and gay Of a bright May morn and a marriage day?â And she sighed in a listless way she had,â âDo not readâit will make me sad!â âWhat shall I do to make you gladâ To make you glad and gay, Till your eyes gleam bright As the stars at night When as light as the light of day?â Sing some song as I twang the strings Of my sweet guitar through its wanderings?â And she sighed in the weary way she had,â âDo not singâit will make me sad!â âWhat can I do to make you gladâ As glad as glad can be, Till your clear eyes seem Like the rays that gleam And glint through a dew-decked tree?â Will it please you, dear, that I now begin A grand old air on my violin?â And she spoke again in the following way,â âYes, oh yes, it would please me, sir; I would be so glad you'd play Some grand old marchâin character,â And then as you march away I will no longer thus be sad, But oh, so gladâso gladâso glad!â MAN'S DEVOTION A lover said, âO Maiden, love me well, For I must go away: And should another ever come to tell Of loveâWhat will you say?â And she let fall a royal robe of hair That folded on his arm And made a golden pillow for her there; Her faceâas bright a charm As ever setting held in kingly crownâ Made answer with a look, And reading it, the lover bended down, And, trusting, âkissed the book.â He took a fond farewell and went away. And slow the time went byâ So wearyâdreary was it, day by day To love, and wait, and sigh. She kissed his pictured face sometimes, and said: âO Lips, so cold and dumb, I would that you would tell me, if not dead, Why, why do you not come?â The picture, smiling, stared her in the face Unmovedâe'en with the touch Of tear-dropsâhersâbejeweling the caseâ 'Twas plainâshe loved him much. And, thus she grew to think of him as gay And joyous all the while, And she was sorrowingââAh, welladay!â But pictures always smile! And yearsâdull yearsâin dull monotony As ever went and came, Still weaving changes on unceasingly, And changing, changed her name. Was she untrue?âShe oftentimes was glad And happy as a wife; But one remembrance oftentimes made sad Her matrimonial life.â Though its few years were hardly noted, when Again her path was strown With thornsâthe roses swept away again, And she again alone! And thenâalas! ah then!âher lover came: âI come to claim you nowâ My Darling, for I know you are the same, And I have kept my vow Through these long, long, long years, and now no more Shall we asundered be!â She staggered back and, sinking to the floor, Cried in her agony: âI have been false!â she moaned, âI am not trueâ I am not worthy now, Nor ever can I be a wife to youâ For I have broke my vow!â And as she kneeled there, sobbing at his feet, He calmly spokeâno sign Betrayed his inward agonyââI count you meet To be a wife of mine!â And raised her up forgiven, though untrue; As fond he gazed on her, She sighed,ââSo happy!â And she never knew He was a widower. A BALLAD WITH A SERIOUS CONCLUSION Crowd about me, little childrenâ Come and cluster 'round my knee While I tell a little story That happened once with me. My father he had gone away A-sailing on the foam, Leaving meâthe merest infantâ And my mother dear at home; For my father was a sailor, And he sailed the ocean o'er For full five years ere yet again He reached his native shore. And I had grown up rugged And healthy day by day, Though I was but a puny babe When father went away. Poor mother she would kiss me And look at me and sigh So strangely, oft I wondered And would ask the reason why. And she would answer sadly, Between her sobs and tears,â âYou look so like your father, Far away so many years!â And then she would caress me And brush my hair away, And tell me not to question, But to run about my play. Thus I went playing thoughtfullyâ For that my mother said,â âYou look so like your father!â Kept ringing in my head. So, ranging once the golden sands That looked out on the sea, I called aloud, âMy father dear, Come back to ma and me!â Then I saw a glancing shadow On the sand, and heard the shriek Of a sea-gull flying seaward, And I heard a gruff voice speak:â âAy, ay, my little shipmate, I thought I heard you hail; Were you trumpeting that sea-gull, Or do you see a sail?â And as rough and gruff a sailor As ever sailed the sea Was standing near grotesquely And leering dreadfully. I replied, though I was frightened âIt was my father dear I was calling for across the seaâ I think he didn't hear.â And then the sailor leered again In such a frightful way, And made so many faces I was little loath to stay: But he started fiercely toward meâ Then made a sudden halt And roared, âI think he heard you!â And turned a somersault. Then a wild fear overcame me, And I flew off like the wind, Shrieking âMother!ââand the sailor Just a little way behind! And then my mother heard me, And I saw her shade her eyes, Looking toward me from the doorway, Transfixed with pale surprise For a momentâthen her features Glowed with all their wonted charms As the sailor overtook me, And I fainted in her arms. When I awoke to reason I shuddered with affright Till I felt my mother's presence With a thrill of wild delightâ Till, amid a shower of kisses Falling glad as summer rain, A muffled thunder rumbled,â âIs he coming 'round again?â Then I shrieked and clung unto her, While her features flushed and burned As she told me it was father From a foreign land returned. I saidâwhen I was calm again, And thoughtfully once more Had dwelt upon my mother's words Of just the day before,â âI don't look like my father, As you told me yesterdayâ I know I don'tâor father Would have run the other way.â THE OLD TIMES WERE THE BEST Friends, my heart is half aweary Of its happiness to-night: Though your songs are gay and cheery, And your spirits feather-light, There's a ghostly music haunting Still the heart of every guest And a voiceless chorus chanting That the Old Times were the best. CHORUS All about is bright and pleasant With the sound of song and jest, Yet a feeling's ever present That the Old Times were the best. A SUMMER AFTERNOON A languid atmosphere, a lazy breeze, With labored respiration, moves the wheat From distant reaches, till the golden seas Break in crisp whispers at my feet. My book, neglected of an idle mind, Hides for a moment from the eyes of men; Or, lightly opened by a critic wind, Affrightedly reviews itself again. Off through the haze that dances in the shine The warm sun showers in the open glade, The forest lies, a silhouette design Dimmed through and through with shade. A dreamy day; and tranquilly I lie At anchor from all storms of mental strain; With absent vision, gazing at the sky, âLike one that hears it rain.â The Katydid, so boisterous last night, Clinging, inverted, in uneasy poise, Beneath a wheat-blade, has forgotten quite If âKaty did or didn'tâ make a noise. The twitter, sometimes, of a wayward bird That checks the song abruptly at the sound, And mildly, chiding echoes that have stirred, Sink into silence, all the more profound. And drowsily I hear the plaintive strain Of some poor dove ... Why, I can scarcely keep My heavy eyelidsâthere it is againâ âCoo-coo!ââI mustn'tââCoo-coo!ââfall asleep! AT LAST A dark, tempestuous night; the stars shut in With shrouds of fog; an inky, jet-black blot The firmament; and where the moon has been An hour agone seems like the darkest spot. The weird windâfurious at its demon gameâ Rattles one's fancy like a window-frame. A care-worn face peers out into the dark, And childish facesâfrightened at the gloomâ Grow awed and vacant as they turn to mark The father's as he passes through the room: The gate latch clatters, and wee baby Bess Whispers, âThe doctor's tummin' now, I dess!â The father turns; a sharp, swift flash of pain Flits o'er his face: âAmanda, child! I said A moment sinceâI see I must againâ Go take your little sisters off to bed! There, Effie, Rose, and Clara mustn't cry!â âI tan't he'p itâI'm fyaid 'at mama'll die!â What are his feelings, when this man alone Sits in the silence, glaring in the grate That sobs and sighs on in an undertone As stoicalâimmovable as Fate, While muffled voices from the sick one's room Come in like heralds of a dreaded doom? The door-latch jingles: in the doorway stands The doctor, while the draft puffs in a breathâ The dead coals leap to life, and clap their hands, The flames flash up. A face as pale as death Turns slowlyâteeth tight clenched, and with a look The doctor, through his specs, reads like a book. âCome, brace up, Mayor!âââLet me know the worst!â âW'y you're the biggest fool I ever sawâ Here, Majorâtake a little brandy firstâ There! She's a boyâI mean he isâhurrah!â âWake up the other girlsâand shout for joyâ Eureka is his nameâI've found A BOY!â FARMER WHIPPLEâBACHELOR It's a mystery to see meâa man o' fifty-four, Who's lived a cross old bachelor fer thirty year' and moreâ A-lookin' glad and smilin'! And they's none o' you can say That you can guess the reason why I feel so good to-day! I must tell you all about it! But I'll have to deviate A little in beginnin', so's to set the matter straight As to how it comes to happen that I never took a wifeâ Kindo' âcrawfishâ from the Present to the Springtime of my life! I was brought up in the country: Of a family of fiveâ Three brothers and a sisterâI'm the only one alive,â Fer they all died little babies; and 'twas one o' Mother's ways, You know, to want a daughter; so she took a girl to raise. The sweetest little thing she was, with rosy cheeks, and fatâ We was little chunks o' shavers then about as high as that! But someway we sort o' suited-like! and Mother she'd declare She never laid her eyes on a more lovin' pair Than we was! So we growed up side by side fer thirteen year', And every hour of it she growed to me more dear!â W'y, even Father's dyin', as he did, I do believe Warn't more affectin' to me than it was to see her grieve! I was then a lad o' twenty; and I felt a flash o' pride In thinkin' all depended on me now to pervide Fer Mother and fer Mary; and I went about the place With sleeves rolled upâand workin', with a mighty smilin' face.â Fer somepin' else was workin'! but not a word I said Of a certain sort o' notion that was runnin' through my head,â âSome day I'd maybe marry, and a brother's love was one Thingâa lover's was another!â was the way the notion run! I remember onc't in harvest, when the âcradle-in'â was done, (When the harvest of my summers mounted up to twenty-one), I was ridin' home with Mary at the closin' o' the dayâ A-chawin' straws and thinkin', in a lover's lazy way! And Mary's cheeks was burnin' like the sunset down the lane: I noticed she was thinkin', too, and ast her to explain. Wellâwhen she turned and kissed me, with her arms around meâlaw! I'd a bigger load o' Heaven than I had a load o' straw! I don't p'tend to learnin', but I'll tell you what's a fac', They's a mighty truthful sayin' somers in a' almanacâ Er somersâ'bout âpuore happinessââperhaps some folks'll laugh At the idyââonly lastin' jest two seconds and a half.ââ But it's jest as true as preachin'!âfer that was a sister's kiss, And a sister's lovin' confidence a-tellin' to me this:â âShe was happy, bein' promised to the son o' Farmer Brown.ââ And my feelin's struck a pardnership with sunset and went down! I don't know how I acted, and I don't know what I said,â Fer my heart seemed jest a-turnin' to an ice-cold lump o' lead; And the hosses kind o' glimmered before me in the road, And the lines fell from my fingersâAnd that was all I knowedâ Ferâwell, I don't know how longâThey's a dim rememberence Of a sound o' snortin' horses, and a stake-and-ridered fence A-whizzin' past, and wheat-sheaves a-dancin' in the air, And Mary screamin' âMurder!â and a-runnin' up to where I was layin' by the roadside, and the wagon upside down A-leanin' on the gate-post, with the wheels a-whirlin' roun'! And I tried to raise and meet her, but I couldn't, with a vague Sort o' notion comin' to me that I had a broken leg. Well, the women nussed me through it; but many a time I'd sigh As I'd keep a-gittin' better instid o' goin' to die, And wonder what was left me worth livin' fer below, When the girl I loved was married to another, don't you know! And my thoughts was as rebellious as the folks was good and kind When Brown and Mary marriedâRailly must 'a' been my mind Was kind o' out o' kilter!âfer I hated Brown, you see, Worse'n pizenâand the feller whittled crutches out fer meâ And done a thousand little ac's o' kindness and respec'â And me a-wishin' all the time that I could break his neck! My relief was like a mourner's when the funeral is done When they moved to Illinois in the Fall o' Forty-one. Then I went to work in airnestâI had nothin' much in view But to drownd out rickollectionsâand it kep' me busy, too! But I slowly thrived and prospered, tel Mother used to say She expected yit to see me a wealthy man some day. Then I'd think how little money was, compared to happinessâ And who'd be left to use it when I died I couldn't guess! But I've still kep' speculatin' and a-gainin' year by year, Tel I'm payin' half the taxes in the county, mighty near! Well!âA year ago er better, a letter comes to hand Astin' how I'd like to dicker fer some Illinois landâ âThe feller that had owned it,â it went ahead to state, âHad jest deceased, insolvent, leavin' chance to speculate,ââ And then it closed by sayin' that I'd âbetter come and see.ââ I'd never been West, anyhowâa'most too wild fer me, I'd allus had a notion; but a lawyer here in town Said I'd find myself mistakend when I come to look around. So I bids good-by to Mother, and I jumps aboard the train, A-thinkin' what I'd bring her when I come back home againâ And ef she'd had an idy what the present was to be, I think it's more'n likely she'd 'a' went along with me! Cars is awful tejus ridin', fer all they go so fast! But finally they called out my stoppin'-place at last: And that night, at the tavern, I dreamp' I was a train O' cars, and skeered at somepin', runnin' down a country lane! Well, in the morning airlyâafter huntin' up the manâ The lawyer who was wantin' to swap the piece o' landâ We started fer the country; and I ast the history Of the farmâits former ownerâand so forth, etcetery! Andâwellâit was interestin'âI su'prised him, I suppose, By the loud and frequent manner in which I blowed my nose!â But his su'prise was greater, and it made him wonder more, When I kissed and hugged the widder when she met us at the door!â It was Mary: ... They's a feelin' a-hidin' down in hereâ Of course I can't explain it, ner ever make it clear.â It was with us in that meetin', I don't want you to fergit! And it makes me kind o'nervous when I think about it yit! I bought that farm, and deeded it, afore I left the town, With âtitle clear to mansions in the skies,â to Mary Brown! And fu'thermore, I took her and the childrenâfer you see, They'd never seed their Grandmaâand I fetched 'em home with me. So now you've got an idy why a man o' fifty-four, Who's lived a cross old bachelor fer thirty year' and more, Is a-lookin' glad and smilin'!âAnd I've jest come into town To git a pair o' license fer to marry Mary Brown. MY JOLLY FRIEND'S SECRET Ah, friend of mine, how goes it Since you've taken you a mate?â Your smile, though, plainly shows it Is a very happy state! Dan Cupid's necromancy! You must sit you down and dine, And lubricate your fancy With a glass or two of wine. And as you have âdeserted,â As my other chums have done, While I laugh alone diverted, As you drop off one by oneâ And I've remained unwedded, Tillâyou seeâlook hereâthat I'm, In a manner, âsnatched bald-headedâ By the sportive hand of Time! I'm an âold 'un!â yes, but wrinkles Are not so plenty, quite, As to cover up the twinkles Of the boyâain't I right? Yet, there are ghosts of kisses Under this mustache of mine My mem'ry only misses When I drown 'em out with wine. From acknowledgment so ample, You would hardly take me for What I amâa perfect sample Of a âjolly bachelorâ; Not a bachelor has being When he laughs at married life But his heart and soul's agreeing That he ought to have a wife! Ah, ha! old chum, this claret, Like Fatima, holds the key Of the old Blue-Beardish garret Of my hidden mystery! Did you say you'd like to listen? Ah, my boy! the âSad No More!â And the tear-drops that will glistenâ Turn the catch upon the door, And sit you down beside me, And put yourself at easeâ I'll trouble you to slide me That wine decanter, please; The path is kind o' mazy Where my fancies have to go, And my heart gets sort o' lazy On the journeyâdon't you know? Let me seeâwhen I was twentyâ It's a lordly age, my boy, When a fellow's money's plenty, And the leisure to enjoyâ And a girlâwith hair as golden Asâthat; and lipsâwellâquite As red as this I'm holdin' Between you and the light. And eyes and a complexionâ Ah, heavens!âle'-me-seeâ Well,âjust in this connection,â Did you lock that door for me? Did I start in recitation My past life to recall? Well, that's an indication I am purty tightâthat's all! THE SPEEDING OF THE KING'S SPITE A kingâestranged from his loving Queen By a foolish royal whimâ Tired and sick of the dull routine Of matters surrounding himâ Issued a mandate in this wise:â âThe dower of my daughter's hand I will give to him who holds this prize, The strangest thing in the land.â But the King, sad sooth! in this grim decree Had a motive low and mean;â 'Twas a royal piece of chicanery To harry and spite the Queen; For King though he was, and beyond compare, He had ruled all things save oneâ Then blamed the Queen that his only heir Was a daughterânot a son. The girl had grown, in the mother's care, Like a bud in the shine and shower That drinks of the wine of the balmy air Till it blooms into matchless flower; Her waist was the rose's stem that bore The flowerâand the flower's perfumeâ That ripens on till it bulges o'er With its wealth of bud and bloom. And she had a loverâlowly sprung,â But a purer, nobler heart Never spake in a courtlier tongue Or wooed with a dearer art: And the fair pair paled at the King's decree; But the smiling Fates contrived To have them wed, in a secrecy That the Queen herself connivedâ While the grim King's heralds scoured the land And the countries roundabout, Shouting aloud, at the King's command, A challenge to knave or lout, Prince or peasant,ââThe mighty King Would have ye understand That he who shows him the strangest thing Shall have his daughter's hand!â And thousands flocked to the royal throne, Bringing a thousand things Strange and curious;âOne, a boneâ The hinge of a fairy's wings; And one, the glass of a mermaid queen, Gemmed with a diamond dew, Where, down in its reflex, dimly seen, Her face smiled out at you. One brought a cluster of some strange date, With a subtle and searching tang That seemed, as you tasted, to penetrate The heart like a serpent's fang; And back you fell for a spell entranced, As cold as a corpse of stone, And heard your brains, as they laughed and danced And talked in an undertone. One brought a bird that could whistle a tune So piercingly pure and sweet, That tears would fall from the eyes of the moon In dewdrops at its feet; And the winds would sigh at the sweet refrain, Till they swooned in an ecstacy, To waken again in a hurricane Of riot and jubilee. One brought a lute that was wrought of a shell Luminous as the shine Of a new-born star in a dewy dell,â And its strings were strands of wine That sprayed at the Fancy's touch and fused, As your listening spirit leant Drunken through with the airs that oozed From the o'ersweet instrument. One brought a tablet of ivory Whereon no thing was writ,â But, at nightâand the dazzled eyes would see Flickering lines o'er it,â And each, as you read from the magic tome, Lightened and died in flame, And the memory held but a golden poem Too beautiful to name. Till it seemed all marvels that ever were known Or dreamed of under the sun Were brought and displayed at the royal throne, And put by, one by one;â Till a graybeard monster came to the Kingâ Haggard and wrinkled and oldâ And spread to his gaze this wondrous thing,â A gossamer veil of gold.â Strangely marvelousâmocking the gaze Like a tangle of bright sunshine, Dipping a million glittering rays In a baptism divine: And a maiden, sheened in this gauze attireâ Sifting a glance of her eyeâ Dazzled men's souls with a fierce desire To kiss and caress her andâdie. And the grim King swore by his royal beard That the veil had won the prize, While the gray old monster blinked and leered With his lashless, red-rimmed eyes, As the fainting form of the princess fell, And the mother's heart went wild, Throbbing and swelling a muffled knell For the dead hopes of her child. But her clouded face with a faint smile shone, As suddenly, through the throng, Pushing his way to the royal throne, A fair youth strode along, While a strange smile hovered about his eyes, As he said to the grim old King:â âThe veil of gold must lose the prize; For I have a stranger thing.â He bent and whispered a sentence brief; But the monarch shook his head, With a look expressive of unbeliefâ âIt can't be so,â he said; âOr give me proof; and I, the King, Give you my daughter's hand,â For certes THAT is a stranger thingâ The strangest thing in the land!â Then the fair youth, turning, caught the Queen In a rapturous caress, While his lithe form towered in lordly mien, As he said in a brief address:â âMy fair bride's mother is this; and, lo, As you stare in your royal awe, By this pure kiss do I proudly show A love for a mother-in-law!â Then a thaw set in the old King's mood, And a sweet Spring freshet came Into his eyes, and his heart renewed Its love for the favored dame: But often he has been heard to declare That âhe never could clearly see How, in the deuce, such a strange affair Could have ended so happily!â JOB WORK âWrite me a rhyme of the present timeâ And the poet took his pen And wrote such lines as the miser minds Hide in the hearts of men. He grew enthused, as the poets used When their fingers kissed the strings Of some sweet lyre, and caught the fire True inspiration brings, And sang the song of a nation's wrongâ Of the patriot's galling chain, And the glad release that the angel, Peace, Has given him again. He sang the lay of religion's sway, Where a hundred creeds clasp hands And shout in glee such a symphony That the whole world understands. He struck the key of monopoly, And sang of her swift decay, And traveled the track of the railway back With a blithesome roundelayâ Of the tranquil bliss of a true love kiss; And painted the picture, too, Of the wedded life, and the patient wife, And the husband fond and true; And sang the joy that a noble boy Brings to a father's soul, Who lets the wine as a mocker shine Stagnated in the bowl. And he stabbed his pen in the ink again, And wrote, with a writhing frown, âThis is the end.â âAnd now, my friend, You may print itâupside down!â PRIVATE THEATRICALS A quite convincing axiom Is, âLife is like a playâ; For, turning back its pages some Few dog-eared years away, I find where I Committed my Love-taleâwith brackets where to sigh. I feel an idle interest To read again the page; I enter, as a lover dressed, At twenty years of age, And play the part With throbbing heart, And all an actor's glowing art. And she who plays my Lady-love Excels!âHer loving glance Has power her audience to moveâ I am her audience.â Her acting tact, To tell the fact, âBrings down the houseâ in every act. And often we defy the curse Of storms and thunder-showers, To meet together and rehearse This little play of oursâ I think, when she âMakes loveâ to me, She kisses very naturally! Yes; it's convincingâratherâ That âLife is like a playâ: I am playing âHeavy Fatherâ In a âScreaming Farceâ to-day, That so âbrings down The house,â I frown, And fain would âring the curtain down.â PLAIN SERMONS I saw a manâand envied him besideâ Because of this world's goods he had great store; But even as I envied him, he died, And left me envious of him no more. I saw another manâand envied stillâ Because he was content with frugal lot; But as I envied him, the rich man's will Bequeathed him all, and envy I forgot. Yet still another man I saw, and he I envied for a calm and tranquil mind That nothing fretted in the least degreeâ Until, alas! I found that he was blind. What vanity is envy! for I find I have been rich in dross of thought, and poor In that I was a fool, and lastly blindâ For never having seen myself before! âTRADIN' JOEâ I'm one o' these cur'ous kind o' chaps You think you know when you don't, perhaps! I hain't no foolâner I don't p'tend To be so smart I could rickommend Myself fer a congressman, my friend!â But I'm kind o' betwixt-and-between, you know,â One o' these fellers 'at folks call âslow.â And I'll say jest here I'm kind o' queer Regardin' things 'at I see and hear,â Fer I'm thick o' hearin' sometimes, and It's hard to git me to understand; But other times it hain't, you bet! Fer I don't sleep with both eyes shet! I've swapped a power in stock, and so The neighbers calls me âTradin' Joeââ And I'm goin' to tell you 'bout a trade,â And one o' the best I ever made: Folks has gone so fur's to say 'At I'm well fixed, in a worldly way, And bein' so, and a widower, It's not su'prisin', as you'll infer, I'm purty handy among the sectâ Widders especially, rickollect! And I won't deny that along o' late I've hankered a heap fer the married stateâ But some way o' 'nother the longer we wait The harder it is to discover a mate. Marshall Thomas,âa friend o' mine, Doin' some in the tradin' line, But a'most too young to know it allâ On'y at picnics er some ball!â Says to me, in a banterin' way, As we was a-loadin' stock one day,â âYou're a-huntin' a wife, and I want you to see My girl's mother, at Kankakee!â She hain't over fortyâgood-lookin' and spry, And jest the woman to fill your eye! And I'm a-goin' there Sund'y,âand now,â says he, âI want to take you along with me; And you marry her, and,â he says, âby 'shaw! You'll hev me fer yer son-in-law!â I studied a while, and says I, âWell, I'll First have to see ef she suits my style; And ef she does, you kin bet your life Your mother-in-law will be my wife!â Well, Sund'y come; and I fixed up someâ Putt on a collarâI did, by gum!â Got down my âplug,â and my satin vestâ (You wouldn't know me to see me dressed!â But any one knows ef you got the clothes You kin go in the crowd wher' the best of 'em goes!) And I greeced my boots, and combed my hair Keerfully over the bald place there; And Marshall Thomas and me that day Eat our dinners with Widder Gray And her girl Han'! Well, jest a glance O' the widder's smilin' countenance, A-cuttin' up chicken and big pot-pies, Would make a man hungry in Paradise! And passin' p'serves and jelly and cake 'At would make an angel's appetite ache!â Pourin' out coffee as yaller as goldâ Twic't as much as the cup could holdâ La! it was rich!âAnd then she'd say, âTake some o' this!â in her coaxin' way, Tell ef I'd been a hoss I'd 'a' foundered, shore, And jest dropped dead on her white-oak floor! Well, the way I talked would 'a' done you good, Ef you'd 'a' been there to 'a' understood; Tel I noticed Hanner and Marshall, they Was a-noticin' me in a cur'ous way; So I says to myse'f, says I, âNow, Joe, The best thing fer you is to jest go slow!â And I simmered down, and let them do The bulk o' the talkin' the evening through. And Marshall was still in a talkative gait When he left, that eveningâtolable late. âHow do you like her?â he says to me; Says I, âShe suits, to a ât-y-Teeâ!â And then I ast how matters stood With him in the opposite neighberhood? âBully!â he says; âI ruther guess I'll finally git her to say the âyes.â I named it to her to-night, and she Kind o' smiled, and said âshe'd seeââ And that's a purty good sign!â says he: âYes,â says I, âyou're ahead o' me!â And then he laughed, and said, âGo in!â And patted me on the shoulder ag'in. Well, ever sense then I've been ridin' a good Deal through the Kankakee neighberhood; And I make it convenient sometimes to stop And hitch a few minutes, and kind o' drop In at the widder's, and talk o' the crop And one thing o' 'nother. And week afore last The notion struck me, as I drove past, I'd stop at the place and state my caseâ Might as well do it at first as last! I felt first-rate; so I hitched at the gate, And went up to the house; and, strange to relate, Marshall Thomas had dropped in, too.â âGlad to see you, sir, how do you do?â He says, says he! Wellâit sounded queer: And when Han' told me to take a cheer, Marshall got up and putt out o' the roomâ And motioned his hand fer the widder to come. I didn't say nothin' fer quite a spell, But thinks I to myse'f, âThere's a dog in the well!â And Han' she smiled so cur'ous at meâ Says I, âWhat's up?â And she says, says she, âMarshall's been at me to marry ag'in, And I told him âno,â jest as you come in.â Well, somepin' o' 'nother in that girl's voice Says to me, âJoseph, here's your choice!â And another minute her guileless breast Was lovin'ly throbbin' ag'in my vest!â And then I kissed her, and heerd a smack Come like a' echo a-flutterin' back, And we looked around, and in full view Marshall was kissin' the widder, too! Well, we all of us laughed, in our glad su'prise, Tel the tears come a-streamin' out of our eyes! And when Marsh said â'Twas the squarest trade That ever me and him had made,â We both shuck hands, 'y jucks! and swore We'd stick together ferevermore. And old Squire Chipman tuck us the trip: And Marshall and me's in pardnership! DOT LEEDLE BOY Ot's a leedle Gristmas story Dot I told der leedle folksâ Und I vant you stop dot laughin' Und grackin' funny jokes!â So help me Peter-Moses! Ot's no time for monkey-shine, Ober I vast told you somedings Of dot leedle boy of mine! Ot vas von cold Vinter vedder, Ven der snow vas all aboutâ Dot you have to chop der hatchet Eef you got der sauerkraut! Und der cheekens on der hind leg Vas standin' in der shine Der sun shmile out dot morning On dot leedle boy of mine. He vas yoost a leedle baby Not bigger as a doll Dot time I got acquaintetâ Ach! you ought to heard 'im squall!â I grackys! dot's der moosic Ot make me feel so fine Ven first I vas been marrietâ Oh, dot leedle boy of mine! He look yoost like his fader!â So, ven der vimmen said, âVot a purty leedle baby!â Katrina shake der head. ... I dink she must 'a' notice Dot der baby vas a-gryin', Und she cover up der blankets Of dot leedle boy of mine. Vel, ven he vas got bigger, Dot he grawl und bump his nose, Und make der table over, Und molasses on his glothesâ Dot make 'im all der sveeter,â So I say to my Katrine, âBetter you vas quit a-shpankin' Dot leedle boy of mine!â No more he vas older As about a dozen months He speak der English language Und der Germanâbote at vonce! Und he dringk his glass of lager Like a Londsman fon der Rhineâ Und I klingk my glass togeder Mit dot leedle boy of mine! I vish you could 'a' seen idâ Ven he glimb up on der chair Und shmash der lookin'-glasses Ven he try to comb his hair Mit a hammer!âUnd Katrina Say, âDot's an ugly sign!â But I laugh und vink my fingers At dot leedle boy of mine. But vonce, dot Vinter morning, He shlip out in der snow Mitout no stockin's on 'im.â He say he âvant to go Und fly some mit der birdies!â Und ve give 'im medi-cine Ven he catch der âparrygoricââ Dot leedle boy of mine! Und so I set und nurse 'im, Vile der Gristmas vas come roun', Und I told 'im 'bout âKriss Kringle,â How he come der chimbly down: Und I ask 'im eef he love 'im Eef he bring 'im someding fine? âNicht besser as mein fader,â Say dot leedle boy of mine.â Und he put his arms aroun' me Und hug so close und tight, I hear der gclock a-tickin' All der balance of der night! ... Someding make me feel so funny Ven I say to my Katrine, âLet us go und fill der stockin's Of dot leedle boy of mine.â Vell.âVe buyed a leedle horses Dot you pull 'im mit a shtring, Und a leedle fancy jay-birdâ Eef you vant to hear 'im sing You took 'im by der topknot Und yoost blow in behineâ Und dot make much spectakel For dot leedle boy of mine! Und gandies, nuts und raizensâ Und I buy a leedle drum Dot I vant to hear 'im rattle Ven der Gristmas morning come! Und a leedle shmall tin rooster Dot vould crow so loud und fine Ven he sqveeze 'im in der morning, Dot leedle boy of mine! Undâvile ve vas a-fixin'â Dot leedle boy vake out! I t'ought he been a-dreamin' âKriss Kringleâ vas about,â For he sayââDot's him!âI see 'im Mit der shtars dot make der shine!â Und he yoost keep on a-gryin'â Dot leedle boy of mine,â Und gottin' vorse und vorserâ Und tumble on der bed! Soâven der doctor seen id, He kindo' shake his head, Und feel his pulseâund visper, âDer boy is a-dyin'.â You dink I could believe id?â Dot leedle boy of mine? I told you, friendsâdot's someding, Der last time dot he speak Und say, âGoot-by, Kriss Kringle!â âDot make me feel so veak I yoost kneel down und drimble, Und bur-sed out a-gryin', âMein Gott, mein Gott in Himmel!â Dot leedle boy of mine!â Der sun don't shine dot Gristmas! ... Eef dot leedle boy vould liff'dâ No deefer-en'! for Heaven vas His leedle Gristmas gift! Und der rooster, und der gandy, Und meâund my Katrineâ Und der jay-birdâis a-vaiting For dot leedle boy of mine. I SMOKE MY PIPE I can't extend to every friend In need a helping handâ No matter though I wish it so, 'Tis not as Fortune planned; But haply may I fancy they Are men of different stripe Than others think who hint and wink,â And soâI smoke my pipe! A golden coal to crown the bowlâ My pipe and I alone,â I sit and muse with idler views Perchance than I should own:â It might be worse to own the purse Whose glutted bowels gripe In little qualms of stinted alms; And so I smoke my pipe. And if inclined to moor my mind And cast the anchor Hope, A puff of breath will put to death The morbid misanthrope That lurks insideâas errors hide In standing forms of type To mar at birth some line of worth; And so I smoke my pipe. The subtle stings misfortune flings Can give me little pain When my narcotic spell has wrought This quiet in my brain: When I can waste the past in taste So luscious and so ripe That like an elf I hug myself; And so I smoke my pipe. And wrapped in shrouds of drifting clouds I watch the phantom's flight, Till alien eyes from Paradise Smile on me as I write: And I forgive the wrongs that live, As lightly as I wipe Away the tear that rises here; And so I smoke my pipe. RED RIDING-HOOD Sweet little myth of the nursery storyâ Earliest love of mine infantile breast, Be something tangible, bloom in thy glory Into existence, as thou art addressed! Hasten! appear to me, guileless and goodâ Thou are so dear to me, Red Riding-Hood! Azure-blue eyes, in a marvel of wonder, Over the dawn of a blush breaking out; Sensitive nose, with a little smile under Trying to hide in a blossoming poutâ Couldn't be serious, try as you would, Little mysterious Red Riding-Hood! Hah! little girl, it is desolate, lonely, Out in this gloomy old forest of Life!â Here are not pansies and buttercups onlyâ Brambles and briers as keen as a knife; And a Heart, ravenous, trails in the wood For the meal have he must,âRed Riding-Hood! IF I KNEW WHAT POETS KNOW If I knew what poets know, Would I write a rhyme Of the buds that never blow In the summer-time? Would I sing of golden seeds Springing up in ironweeds? And of rain-drops turned to snow, If I knew what poets know? Did I know what poets do, Would I sing a song Sadder than the pigeon's coo When the days are long? Where I found a heart in pain, I would make it glad again; And the false should be the true, Did I know what poets do. If I knew what poets know, I would find a theme Sweeter than the placid flow Of the fairest dream: I would sing of love that lives On the errors it forgives; And the world would better grow If I knew what poets know. AN OLD SWEETHEART OF MINE An old sweetheart of mine!âIs this her presence here with me, Or but a vain creation of a lover's memory? A fair, illusive vision that would vanish into air Dared I even touch the silence with the whisper of a prayer? Nay, let me then believe in all the blended false and trueâ The semblance of the old love and the substance of the new,â The then of changeless sunny daysâthe now of shower and shineâ But Love forever smilingâas that old sweetheart of mine. This ever-restful sense of home, though shouts ring in the hall.â The easy chairâthe old book-shelves and prints along the wall; The rare Habanas in their box, or gaunt church-warden-stem That often wags, above the jar, derisively at them. As one who cons at evening o'er an album, all alone, And muses on the faces of the friends that he has known, So I turn the leaves of Fancy, till, in shadowy design, I find the smiling features of an old sweetheart of mine. The lamplight seems to glimmer with a flicker of surprise, As I turn it lowâto rest me of the dazzle in my eyes, And light my pipe in silence, save a sigh that seems to yoke Its fate with my tobacco and to vanish with the smoke. 'Tis a fragrant retrospection,âfor the loving thoughts that start Into being are like perfume from the blossom of the heart; And to dream the old dreams over is a luxury divineâ When my truant fancies wander with that old sweetheart of mine. Though I hear beneath my study, like a fluttering of wings, The voices of my children and the mother as she singsâ I feel no twinge of conscience to deny me any theme When Care has cast her anchor in the harbor of a dreamâ In fact, to speak in earnest, I believe it adds a charm To spice the good a trifle with a little dust of harm,â For I find an extra flavor in Memory's mellow wine That makes me drink the deeper to that old sweetheart of mine. O Childhood-days enchanted! O the magic of the Spring!â With all green boughs to blossom white, and all bluebirds to sing! When all the air, to toss and quaff, made life a jubilee And changed the children's song and laugh to shrieks of ecstasy. With eyes half closed in clouds that ooze from lips that taste, as well, The peppermint and cinnamon, I hear the old School bell, And from âRecessâ romp in again from âBlackman'sâ broken line, To smile, behind my âlesson,â at that old sweetheart of mine. A face of lily-beauty, with a form of airy grace, Floats out of my tobacco as the Genii from the vase; And I thrill beneath the glances of a pair of azure eyes As glowing as the summer and as tender as the skies. I can see the pink sunbonnet and the little checkered dress She wore when first I kissed her and she answered the caress With the written declaration that, âas surely as the vine Grew 'round the stamp,â she loved meâthat old sweetheart of mine. Again I made her presents, in a really helpless way,â The big âRhode Island GreeningââI was hungry, too, that day!â But I follow her from Spelling, with her hand behind herâsoâ And I slip the apple in itâand the Teacher doesn't know! I give my treasures to herâall,âmy pencilâblue-and-red;â And, if little girls played marbles, mine should all be hers, instead! But she gave me her photograph, and printed âEver Thineâ Across the backâin blue-and-redâthat old sweetheart of mine! And again I feel the pressure of her slender little hand, As we used to talk together of the future we had planned,â When I should be a poet, and with nothing else to do But write the tender verses that she set the music to ... When we should live together in a cozy little cot Hid in a nest of roses, with a fairy garden-spot, Where the vines were ever fruited, and the weather ever fine, And the birds were ever singing for that old sweetheart of mine. When I should be her lover forever and a day, And she my faithful sweetheart till the golden hair was gray; And we should be so happy that when either's lips were dumb They would not smile in Heaven till the other's kiss had come. But, ah! my dream is broken by a step upon the stair, And the door is softly opened, andâmy wife is standing there: Yet with eagerness and rapture all my visions I resign,â To greet the living presence of that old sweetheart of mine. SQUIRE HAWKINS'S STORY I hain't no hand at tellin' tales, Er spinnin' yarns, as the sailors say; Someway o' 'nother, language fails To slide fer me in the oily way That lawyers has; and I wisht it would, Fer I've got somepin' that I call good; But bein' only a country squire, I've learned to listen and admire, Ruther preferrin' to be addressed Than talk myse'fâbut I'll do my best:â Old Jeff Thompsonâwell, I'll say, Was the clos'test man I ever saw!â Rich as cream, but the porest pay, And the meanest man to work ferâLa! I've knowed that man to work one âhandââ Fer little er nothin', you understandâ From four o'clock in the morning light Tel eight and nine o'clock at night, And then find fault with his appetite! He'd drive all over the neighberhood To miss the place where a toll-gate stood, And slip in town, by some old road That no two men in the country knowed, With a jag o' wood, and a sack o' wheat, That wouldn't burn and you couldn't eat! And the trades he'd make, 'll I jest de-clare, Was enough to make a preacher swear! And then he'd hitch, and hang about Tel the lights in the toll-gate was blowed out, And then the turnpike he'd turn in And sneak his way back home ag'in! Some folks hint, and I make no doubt, That that's what wore his old wife outâ Toilin' away from day to day And year to year, through heat and cold, Uncomplainin'âthe same old way The martyrs died in the days of old; And a-clingin', too, as the martyrs done, To one fixed faith, and her only one,â Little Patience, the sweetest child That ever wept unrickonciled, Er felt the pain and the ache and sting That only a mother's death can bring. Patience Thompson!âI think that name Must 'a' come from a power above, Fer it seemed to fit her jest the same As a gaiter would, er a fine kid glove! And to see that girl, with all the care Of the household on herâI de-clare It was oudacious, the work she'd do, And the thousand plans that she'd putt through; And sing like a medder-lark all day long, And drowned her cares in the joys o' song; And laugh sometimes tel the farmer's âhand,â Away fur off in the fields, would stand A-listenin', with the plow half drawn, Tel the coaxin' echoes called him on; And the furries seemed, in his dreamy eyes, Like foot-paths a-leadin' to Paradise, As off through the hazy atmosphere The call fer dinner reached his ear. Now love's as cunnin' a little thing As a hummin'-bird upon the wing, And as liable to poke his nose Jest where folks would least suppose,â And more'n likely build his nest Right in the heart you'd leave unguessed, And live and thrive at your expenseâ At least, that's my experience. And old Jeff Thompson often thought, In his se'fish way, that the quiet John Was a stiddy chap, as a farm-hand ought To always be,âfer the airliest dawn Found John busyâand âeasy,â too, Whenever his wages would fall due!â To sum him up with a final touch, He eat so little and worked so much, That old Jeff laughed to hisse'f and said, âHe makes me money and airns his bread!â But John, fer all of his quietude, Would sometimes drap a word er so That none but Patience understood, And none but her was meant to know!â Maybe at meal-times John would say, As the sugar-bowl come down his way, âThanky, no; my coffee's sweet Enough fer me!â with sich conceit, She'd know at once, without no doubt, He meant because she poured it out; And smile and blush, and all sich stuff, And ast ef it was âstrong enough?â And git the answer, neat and trim, âIt couldn't be too âstrongâ fer him!â And so things went fer 'bout a year, Tel John, at last, found pluck to go And pour his tale in the old man's earâ And ef it had been hot lead, I know It couldn't 'a' raised a louder fuss, Ner 'a' riled the old man's temper wuss! He jest lit in, and cussed and swore, And lunged and rared, and ripped and tore, And told John jest to leave his door, And not to darken it no more! But Patience cried, with eyes all wet, âRemember, John, and don't ferget, Whatever comes, I love you yet!â But the old man thought, in his se'fish way, âI'll see her married rich some day; And that,â thinks he, âis money fer meâ And my will's law, as it ought to be!â So when, in the course of a month er so, A widower, with a farm er two, Comes to Jeff's, w'y, the folks, you know, Had to talkâas the folks'll do: It was the talk of the neighberhoodâ Patience and John, and their affairs;â And this old chap with a few gray hairs Had âcut John out,â it was understood. And some folks reckoned âPatience, too, Knowed what she was a-goin' to doâ It was like herâla! indeed!â All she loved was dollars and centsâ Like old Jeffâand they saw no need Fer John to pine at her negligence!â But others said, in a kinder way, They missed the songs she used to singâ They missed the smiles that used to play Over her face, and the laughin' ring Of her glad voiceâthat everything Of her old se'f seemed dead and gone, And this was the ghost that they gazed on! Tel finally it was noised about There was a weddin' soon to be Down at Jeff's; and the âcat was outâ Shore enough!âLl the Jee-mum-nee! It riled me when John told me so,â Fer I was a friend o' John's, you know; And his trimblin' voice jest broke in twoâ As a feller's voice'll sometimes do.â And I says, says I, âEf I know my bizâ And I think I know what jestice is,â I've read some lawâand I'd advise A man like you to wipe his eyes And square his jaws and start ag'in, Fer jestice is a-goin' to win!â And it wasn't long tel his eyes had cleared As blue as the skies, and the sun appeared In the shape of a good old-fashioned smile That I hadn't seen fer a long, long while. So we talked on fer a' hour er more, And sunned ourselves in the open door,â Tel a hoss-and-buggy down the road Come a-drivin' up, that I guess John knowed,â Fer he winked and says, âI'll dessappearâ They'd smell a mice ef they saw me here!â And he thumbled his nose at the old gray mare, And hid hisse'f in the house somewhere. Well.âThe rig drove up: and I raised my head As old Jeff hollered to me and said That âhim and his old friend there had come To see ef the squire was at home.â ... I told 'em âI was; and I aimed to be At every chance of a weddin'-fee!â And then I laughedâand they laughed, too,â Fer that was the object they had in view. âWould I be on hands at eight that night?â They ast; and 's-I, âYou're mighty right, I'll be on hand!â And then I bu'st Out a-laughin' my very wu'st,â And so did they, as they wheeled away And drove to'rds town in a cloud o' dust. Then I shet the door, and me and John Laughed and laughed, and jest laughed on, Tel Mother drapped her specs, and by Jeewhillikers! I thought she'd die!â And she couldn't 'a' told, I'll bet my hat, What on earth she was laughin' at! But all o' the fun o' the tale hain't done!â Fer a drizzlin' rain had jest begun, And a-havin' 'bout four mile' to ride, I jest concluded I'd better light Out fer Jeff's and save my hide,â Fer it was a-goin' to storm, that night! So we went down to the barn, and John Saddled my beast, and I got on; And he told me somepin' to not ferget, And when I left, he was laughin' yet. And, 'proachin' on to my journey's end, The great big draps o' the rain come down, And the thunder growled in a way to lend An awful look to the lowerin' frown The dull sky wore; and the lightnin' glanced Tel my old mare jest more'n pranced, And tossed her head, and bugged her eyes To about four times their natchurl size, As the big black lips of the clouds 'ud drap Out some oath of a thunderclap, And threaten on in an undertone That chilled a feller clean to the bone! But I struck shelter soon enough To save myse'f. And the house was jammed With the women-folks, and the weddin'-stuff:â A great, long table, fairly crammed With big pound-cakesâand chops and steaksâ And roasts and stewsâand stumick-aches Of every fashion, form, and size, From twisters up to punkin-pies! And candies, oranges, and figs, And reezins,âall the âwhilligigsâ And âjim-cracksâ that the law allows On sich occasions!âBobs and bows Of gigglin' girls, with corkscrew curls, And fancy ribbons, reds and blues, And âbeau-ketchersâ and âcurliquesâ To beat the world! And seven o'clock Brought old Jeff;âand broughtâthe groom,â With a sideboard-collar on, and stock That choked him so, he hadn't room To swaller in, er even sneeze, Er clear his th'oat with any ease Er comfortâand a good square cough Would saw his Adam's apple off! But as fer PatienceâMy! Oomh-oomh!â I never saw her look so sweet!â Her face was cream and roses, too; And then them eyes o' heavenly blue Jest made an angel all complete! And when she split 'em up in smiles And splintered 'em around the room, And danced acrost and met the groom, And laughed out loudâIt kind o' spiles My language when I come to thatâ Fer, as she laid away his hat, Thinks I, âThe papers hid inside Of that said hat must make a bride A happy one fer all her life, Er else a wrecked and wretched wife!â And, someway, then, I thought of John,â Then looked towards Patience. ... She was gone!â The door stood open, and the rain Was dashin' in; and sharp and plain Above the storm we heerd a cryâ A ringin', laughin', loud âGood-by!â That died away, as fleet and fast A hoss's hoofs went splashin' past! And that was all. 'Twas done that quick! ... You've heerd o' fellers âlookin' sickâ? I wisht you'd seen the groom jest thenâ I wisht you'd seen them two old men, With starin' eyes that fairly glared At one another, and the scared And empty faces of the crowd,â I wisht you could 'a' been allowed To jest look on and see it all,â And heerd the girls and women bawl And wring their hands; and heerd old Jeff A-cussin' as he swung hisse'f Upon his hoss, who champed his bit As though old Nick had holt of it: And cheek by jowl the two old wrecks Rode off as though they'd break their necks. And as we all stood starin' out Into the night, I felt the brush Of some one's hand, and turned about, And heerd a voice that whispered, âHush!â They're waitin' in the kitchen, and You're wanted. Don't you understand?â Well, ef my memory serves me now, I think I winked.âWell, anyhow, I left the crowd a-gawkin' there, And jest slipped off around to where The back door opened, and went in, And turned and shet the door ag'in, And maybe locked itâcouldn't swear,â A woman's arms around me makes Me liable to make mistakes.â I read a marriage license nex', But as I didn't have my specs I jest inferred it was all right, And tied the knot so mortal-tight That Patience and my old friend John Was safe enough from that time on! Well, now, I might go on and tell How all the joke at last leaked out, And how the youngsters raised the yell And rode the happy groom about Upon their shoulders; how the bride Was kissed a hundred times beside The one I give her,âtel she cried And laughed untel she like to died! I might go on and tell you all About the supperâand the ball.â You'd ought to see me twist my heel Through jest one old Furginny reel Afore you die! er tromp the strings Of some old fiddle tel she sings Some old cowtillion, don't you know, That putts the devil in yer toe! We kep' the dancin' up tel four O'clock, I reckonâmaybe more.â We hardly heerd the thunders roar, Er thought about the storm that blowedâ And them two fellers on the road! Tel all at onc't we heerd the door Bu'st open, and a voice that swore,â And old Jeff Thompson tuck the floor. He shuck hisse'f and looked around Like some old dog about half-drownedâ His hat, I reckon, weighed ten pound To say the least, and I'll say, shore, His overcoat weighed fifty moreâ The wettest man you ever saw, To have so dry a son-in-law! He sized it all; and Patience laid Her hand in John's, and looked afraid, And waited. And a stiller set O' folks, I know, you never met In any court room, where with dread They wait to hear a verdick read. The old man turned his eyes on me: âAnd have you married 'em?â says he. I nodded âYes.â âWell, that'll do,â He says, âand now we're th'ough with you,â You jest clear out, and I decide And promise to be satisfied!â He hadn't nothin' more to say. I saw, of course, how matters lay, And left. But as I rode away I heerd the roosters crow fer day. A COUNTRY PATHWAY I come upon it suddenly, aloneâ A little pathway winding in the weeds That fringe the roadside; and with dreams my own, I wander as it leads. Full wistfully along the slender way, Through summer tan of freckled shade and shine, I take the path that leads me as it mayâ Its every choice is mine. A chipmunk, or a sudden-whirring quail, Is startled by my step as on I fareâ A garter-snake across the dusty trail Glances andâis not there. Above the arching jimson-weeds flare twos And twos of sallow-yellow butterflies, Like blooms of lorn primroses blowing loose When autumn winds arise. The trail dipsâdwindlesâbroadens then, and lifts Itself astride a cross-road dubiously, And, from the fennel marge beyond it, drifts Still onward, beckoning me. And though it needs must lure me mile on mile Out of the public highway, still I go, My thoughts, far in advance in Indian file, Allure me even so. Why, I am as a long-lost boy that went At dusk to bring the cattle to the bars, And was not found again, though Heaven lent His mother all the stars With which to seek him through that awful night. O years of nights as vain!âStars never rise But well might miss their glitter in the light Of tears in mother-eyes! Soâon, with quickened breaths, I follow stillâ My avant-courier must be obeyed! Thus am I led, and thus the path, at will, Invites me to invade A meadow's precincts, where my daring guide Clambers the steps of an old-fashioned stile, And stumbles down again, the other side, To gambol there a while. In pranks of hide-and-seek, as on ahead I see it running, while the clover-stalks Shake rosy fists at me, as though they saidâ âYou dog our country walks âAnd mutilate us with your walking-stick!â We will not suffer tamely what you do, And warn you at your peril,âfor we'll sick Our bumblebees on you!â But I smile back, in airy nonchalance,â The more determined on my wayward quest, As some bright memory a moment dawns A morning in my breastâ Sending a thrill that hurries me along In faulty similes of childish skips, Enthused with lithe contortions of a song Performing on my lips. In wild meanderings o'er pasture wealthâ Erratic wanderings through dead'ning lands, Where sly old brambles, plucking me by stealth, Put berries in my hands: Or the path climbs a boulderâwades a sloughâ Or, rollicking through buttercups and flags, Goes gaily dancing o'er a deep bayou On old tree-trunks and snags: Or, at the creek, leads o'er a limpid pool Upon a bridge the stream itself has made, With some Spring-freshet for the mighty tool That its foundation laid. I pause a moment here to bend and muse, With dreamy eyes, on my reflection, where A boat-backed bug drifts on a helpless cruise, Or wildly oars the air, As, dimly seen, the pirate of the brookâ The pike, whose jaunty hulk denotes his speedâ Swings pivoting about, with wary look Of low and cunning greed. Till, filled with other thought, I turn again To where the pathway enters in a realm Of lordly woodland, under sovereign reign Of towering oak and elm. A puritanic quiet here reviles The almost whispered warble from the hedge, And takes a locust's rasping voice and files The silence to an edge. In such a solitude my somber way Strays like a misanthrope within a gloom Of his own shadowsâtill the perfect day Bursts into sudden bloom, And crowns a long, declining stretch of space, Where King Corn's armies lie with flags unfurled, And where the valley's dint in Nature's face Dimples a smiling world. And lo! through mists that may not be dispelled, I see an old homestead, as in dreams, Where, like a gem in costly setting held, The old log cabin gleams. O darling Pathway! lead me bravely on Adown your valley-way, and run before Among the roses crowding up the lawn And thronging at the door,â And carry up the echo there that shall Arouse the drowsy dog, that he may bay The household out to greet the prodigal That wanders home to-day. THE OLD GUITAR Neglected now is the old guitar And moldering into decay; Fretted with many a rift and scar That the dull dust hides away, While the spider spins a silver star In its silent lips to-day. The keys hold only nerveless stringsâ The sinews of brave old airs Are pulseless now; and the scarf that clings So closely here declares A sad regret in its ravelings And the faded hue it wears. But the old guitar, with a lenient grace, Has cherished a smile for me; And its features hint of a fairer face That comes with a memory Of a flower-and-perfume-haunted place And a moonlit balcony. Music sweeter than words confess, Or the minstrel's powers invent, Thrilled here once at the light caress Of the fairy hands that lent This excuse for the kiss I press On the dear old instrument. The rose of pearl with the jeweled stem Still blooms; and the tiny sets In the circle all are here; the gem In the keys, and the silver frets; But the dainty fingers that danced o'er themâ Alas for the heart's regrets!â Alas for the loosened strings to-day, And the wounds of rift and scar On a worn old heart, with its roundelay Enthralled with a stronger bar That Fate weaves on, through a dull decay Like that of the old guitar! âFRIDAY AFTERNOONâ TO WILLIAM MORRIS PIERSON [1868â1870] Of the wealth of facts and fancies That our memories may recall, The old school-day romances Are the dearest, after all!â When some sweet thought revises The half-forgotten tune That opened âExercisesâ On âFriday Afternoon.â We seem to hear the clicking Of the pencil and the pen, And the solemn, ceaseless ticking Of the timepiece ticking then; And we note the watchful master, As he waves the warning rod, With our own heart beating faster Than the boy's who threw the wad. Some little hand uplifted, And the creaking of a shoe:â A problem left unsifted For the teacher's hand to do: The murmured hum of learningâ And the flutter of a book; The smell of something burning, And the school's inquiring look. The bashful boy in blushes; And the girl, with glancing eyes, Who hides her smiles, and hushes The laugh about to rise,â Then, with a quick invention, Assumes a serious face, To meet the words, âAttenton! Every scholar in his place!â The opening song, page 20.â Ah! dear old âGolden Wreath,â You willed your sweets in plenty; And some who look beneath The leaves of Time will linger, And loving tears will start, As Fancy trails her finger O'er the index of the heart. âGood News from HomeââWe hear it Welling tremulous, yet clear And holy as the spirit Of the song we used to hearâ âGood news for meââ(A throbbing And an aching melody)â âHas come across theââ(sobbing, Yea, and salty) âdark blue sea!â Or the pÃ¦an âScotland's burning!â With its mighty surge and swell Of chorus, still returning To its universal yellâ Till we're almost glad to drop to Something sad and full of painâ And âSkip verse three,â and stop, too, Ere our hearts are broke again. Then âthe big girls'â compositions, With their doubt, and hope, and glow Of heart and face,âconditions Of âthe big boysââeven so,â When themes of âSpring,â and âSummerâ And of âFall,â and âWinter-timeâ Droop our heads and hold us dumber Than the sleigh-bell's fancied chime. For it goes ahead and mentions âIf a certain Mr. O. Has serious intentions That he ought to tell her so.â It also âAsks permission To intimate to âJohnâ The dubious condition Of the ground he's standing onâ; And, dropping the suggestion To âmind what he's about,â It stuns him with the question: âDoes his mother know he's out?â And among the contributions To this âAcademic Pressâ Are âVersified Effusionsâ ByââOur lady editressââ Which fact is proudly stated By the Chief of the concern,â âThough the verse communicated Bears the pen-name âFanny Fern.ââ When all has been recited, And the teacher's bell is heard, And visitors, invited, Have dropped a kindly word, A hush of holy feeling Falls down upon us there, As though the day were kneeling, With the twilight for the prayer. Midst the wealth of facts and fancies That our memories may recall, Thus the old school-day romances Are the dearest, after all!â When some sweet thought revises The half-forgotten tune That opened âExcercises,â On âFriday Afternoon.â âJOHNSON'S BOYâ The world is turned ag'in' me, And people says, âThey guess That nothin' else is in me But pure maliciousness!â I git the blame for doin' What other chaps destroy, And I'm a-goin' to ruin Because I'm âJohnson's boy.â That ain't my nameâI'd ruther They'd call me Ike or Patâ But they've forgot the otherâ And so have I, for that! I reckon it's as handy, When Nibsy breaks his toy, Or some one steals his candy, To say 'twas âJohnson's boy!â You can't git any water At the pump, and find the spout So durn chuck-full o' mortar That you have to bore it out; You tackle any scholar In Wisdom's wise employ, And I'll bet you half a dollar He'll say it's âJohnson's boy!â Folks don't know how I suffer In my uncomplainin' wayâ They think I'm gittin' tougher And tougher every day. Last Sunday night, when Flinder Was a-shoutin' out for joy, And some one shook the winder, He prayed for âJohnson's boy.â I'm tired of bein' follered By farmers every day, And then o' bein' collared For coaxin' hounds away; Hounds always plays me doubleâ It's a trick they all enjoyâ To git me into trouble, Because I'm âJohnson's boy.â But if I git to Heaven, I hope the Lord'll see Some boy has been perfect, And lay it on to me; I'll swell the song sonorous, And clap my wings for joy, And sail off on the chorusâ âHurrah for âJohnson's boy!ââ HER BEAUTIFUL HANDS O your handsâthey are strangely fair! Fairâfor the jewels that sparkle there,â Fairâfor the witchery of the spell That ivory keys alone can tell; But when their delicate touches rest Here in my own do I love them best, As I clasp with eager, acquisitive spans My glorious treasure of beautiful hands! Marvelousâwonderfulâbeautiful hands! They can coax roses to bloom in the strands Of your brown tresses; and ribbons will twine, Under mysterious touches of thine, Into such knots as entangle the soul And fetter the heart under such a control As only the strength of my love understandsâ My passionate love for your beautiful hands. As I remember the first fair touch Of those beautiful hands that I love so much, I seem to thrill as I then was thrilled, Kissing the glove that I found unfilledâ When I met your gaze, and the queenly bow, As you said to me, laughingly, âKeep it now!â ... And dazed and alone in a dream I stand, Kissing this ghost of your beautiful hand. When first I loved, in the long ago, And held your hand as I told you soâ Pressed and caressed it and gave it a kiss And said âI could die for a hand like this!â Little I dreamed love's fullness yet Had to ripen when eyes were wet And prayers were vain in their wild demands For one warm touch of your beautiful hands. Beautiful Hands!âO Beautiful Hands!
