A'nty he'p me, 'til I be Purt' nigh strip-pudânen hug me In bofe arms an' lif' me 'way Up in her high bedâan' pray Wiv me,â'bout my Maâan' Paâ An' ole Santy Clausâan' Sleighâ An' Reindeers an' little Drumâ Yes, an' Picture-books, âTom Thumb,â An' âThree Bears,â an' ole âFee-Fawââ Yes, an' âTweedle-Deeâ an' âDum,â An' âWhite Knightâ an' âSquidjicum,â An' most things you ever saw!â An' when A'nty kissed me, she 'Uz all cryin' over me! Don't want Santy Clausâner things Any kind he ever brings!â Don't want A'ntyâDon't want Pa!â I ist only want my Ma! TO ALMON KEEFER INSCRIBED IN âTALES OF THE OCEANâ This first book that I ever knew Was read aloud to me by youâ Friend of my boyhood, therefore take It back from me, for old times' sakeâ The selfsame âTalesâ first read to me, Under âthe old sweet apple tree,â Ere I myself could read such great Big words,âbut listening all elate, At your interpreting, until Brain, heart and soul were all athrill With wonder, awe, and sheer excess Of wildest childish happiness. So take the book againâforget All else,âlong years, lost hopes, regret; Sighs for the joys we ne'er attain, Prayers we have lifted all in vain; Tears for the faces seen no more, Once as the roses at the door! Take the enchanted bookâAnd lo, On grassy swards of long ago, Sprawl out again, beneath the shade The breezy old-home orchard made, The veriest barefoot boy indeedâ And I will listen as you read. LITTLE MAID-O'-DREAMS Little Maid-o'-Dreams, with your Eery eyes so clear and pure Gazing, where we fain would see Into far futurity,â Tell us what you there behold, In your visions manifold! What is on beyond our sight, Biding till the morrow's light, Fairer than we see to-day, As our dull eyes only may? Little Maid-o'-Dreams, with face Like as in some woodland place Lifts a lily, chaste and white, From the shadow to the light;â Tell us, by your subtler glance, What strange sorcery enchants You as now,âhere, yet afar As the realms of moon and star?â Have you magic lamp and ring, And genii for vassaling? Little Maid-o'-Dreams, confess You're divine and nothing less,â For with mortal palms, we fear, Yet must pet you, dreaming hereâ Yearning, too, to lift the tips Of your fingers to our lips; Fearful still you may rebel, High and heav'nly oracle! Thus, though all unmeet our kiss, Pardon this!âand this!âand this! Little Maid-o'-Dreams, we call Truce and favor, knowing all!â All your magic is, in truth, Pure foresight and faith of youthâ You're a child, yet even so, You're a sage, in embryoâ Prescient poetâartistâgreat As your dreams anticipate.â Trusting God and Man, you do Just as Heaven inspires you to. EDGAR WILSON NYE FEBRUARY 22, 1896 The saddest silence falls when Laughter lays Finger on lip, and falteringly breaks The glad voice into dying minor shakes And quavers, lorn as airs the wind-harp plays At urge of drearest Winter's bleakest days: A troubled hush, in which all hope forsakes Us, and the yearning upstrained vision aches With tears that drown e'en heaven from our gaze. Such silenceâafter such glad merriment! O prince of halest humor, wit and cheer! Could you yet speak to us, I doubt not we Should catch your voice, still blithely eloquent Above all murmurings of sorrow here, Calling your love back to us laughingly.

VOLUME VII CASSANDER âCassander! O Cassander!ââher mother's voice seems cle'r As ever, from the old back-porch, a-hollerin' fer herâ Especially in airly Springâlike May, two year' agoâ Last time she hollered fer her,âand Cassander didn't hear! Cassander was so chirpy-like and sociable and free, And good to ever'body, and wuz even good to me Though I wuz jes' a commonâwell, a farm-hand, don't you know, A-workin' on her father's place, as pore as pore could be! Her bein' jes' a' only child, Cassander had her way A good-'eal more'n other girls; and neighbers ust to say She looked most like her Mother, but wuz turned most like her Pap,â Except he had no use fer town-folks thenâner yit to-day! I can't claim she incouraged me: She'd let me drive her in To town sometimes, on Saturd'ys, and fetch her home ag'in, Tel onc't she 'scused âOld Mollâ and me,âand some blame' city-chap, He driv her home, two-forty style, in face o' kith-and-kin. She even tried to make him stay fer supper, but I 'low He must 'a' kind o' 'spicioned some objections.âAnyhow, Her mother callin' at her, whilst her father stood and shook His fist,âthe town-chap turnt his team and made his partin' bow. âCassander! You, Cassander!ââhear her mother jes' as plain, And see Cassander blushin' like the peach tree down the lane, Whilse I sneaked on apast her, with a sort o' hang-dog look, A-feelin' cheap as sorghum and as green as sugarcane! (You see, I'd skooted when she met her town-beauâwhen, in fact, Ef I'd had sense I'd stayed fer her.âBut sense wuz what I lacked! So I'd cut home ahead o' her, so's I could tell 'em what Wuz keepin' her. Andâyou know how a jealous fool'll act!) I past her, I wuz sayin',âbut she never turnt her head; I swallered-like and cle'red my th'oatâbut that wuz all I said; And whilse I hoped fer some word back, it wuzn't what I got.â That girl'll not stay stiller on the day she's layin' dead! Well, that-air silence lasted!âUst to listen ever' day I'd be at work and hear her mother callin' thataway; I'd sight Cassander, mayby, cuttin' home acrost the blue And drizzly fields; but nary answerânary word to say! Putt in about two weeks o' thatâtwo weeks o' rain and mud, Er mostly so: I couldn't plow. The old crick like a flood: And, lonesome as a borried dog, I'd wade them old woods throughâ The dogwood blossoms white as snow, and redbuds red as blood. Last time her mother called herâsich a morning like as now: The robins and the bluebirds, and the blossoms on the boughâ And this wuz yit 'fore brekfust, with the sun out at his best, And hosses kickin' in the barnâand dry enough to plow. âCassander! O Cassander!â ... And her only answerâWhat?â A letter, twisted round the cook-stove damper, smokin'-hot, A-statin': âI wuz married on that day of all the rest, The day my husband fetched me homeâef you ain't all fergot!â âCassander! O Cassander!â seems, allus, 'long in May, I hear her mother callin' herâa-callin', night and dayâ âCassander! O Cassander!â allus callin', as I say, âCassander; O Cassander!â jes' a-callin' thataway. A CHILD-WORLD PROEM The Child-Worldâlong and long since lost to viewâ A Fairy Paradise!â How always fair it was and fresh and newâ How every affluent hour heaped heart and eyes With treasures of surprise! Enchantments tangible: The under-brink Of dawns that launched the sight Up seas of gold: The dewdrop on the pink, With all the green earth in it and blue height Of heavens infinite: The liquid, dripping songs of orchard-birdsâ The wee bass of the bees,â With lucent deeps of silence afterwards; The gay, clandestine whisperings of the breeze And glad leaves of the trees. O Child-World: After this worldâjust as when I found you first sufficed My soulmost needâif I found you again, With all my childish dream so realized, I should not be surprised. THE CHILD-WORLD A child-world, yet a wondrous world no less, To those who knew its boundless happiness. A simple old frame houseâeight rooms in allâ Set just one side the center of a small But very hopeful Indiana town,â The upper story looking squarely down Upon the main street, and the main highway From East to West,âhistoric in its day, Known as The National Roadâold-timers, all Who linger yet, will happily recall It as the scheme and handiwork, as well As property, of âUncle Sam,â and tell Of its importance, âlong and long afore Railroads wuz ever dreamp' of!ââFurthermore, The reminiscent first inhabitants Will make that old road blossom with romance Of snowy caravans, in long parade Of covered vehicles, of every grade From ox-cart of most primitive design, To Conestoga wagons, with their fine Deep-chested six-horse teams, in heavy gear, High hames and chiming bellsâto childish ear And eye entrancing as the glittering train Of some sun-smitten pageant of old Spain. And, in like spirit, haply they will tell You of the roadside forests, and the yell Of âwolfsâ and âpainters,â in the long night-ride, And âscreechin' catamountsâ on every side.â Of stage-coach days, highwaymen, and strange crimes, And yet unriddled mysteries of the times Called âGood Old.â âAnd why âGood Oldâ?â once a rare Old chronicler was asked, who brushed the hair Out of his twinkling eyes and said,ââWell, John, They're âgood old timesâ because they're dead and gone!â The old home site was portioned into three Distinctive lots. The front oneânatively Facing to southward, broad and gaudy-fine With lilac, dahlia, rose, and flowering vineâ The dwelling stood in; and behind that, and Upon the alley north and south, left hand, The old woodhouse,âhalf, trimly stacked with wood, And half, a workshop, where a work-bench stood Steadfastly through all seasons.âOver it, Along the wall, hung compass, brace-and-bit, And square, and drawing-knife, and smoothing-planeâ And a little jack-plane, tooâthe children's vain Possession by pretenseâin fancy they Manipulating it in endless play, Turning out countless curls and loops of bright, Fine satin shavingsâRapture infinite! Shelved quilting-frames; the tool-chest; the old box Of refuse nails and screws; a rough gun-stock's Outline in âcurly mapleâ; and a pair Of clamps and old kraut-cutter hanging there. Some âpatterns,â in thin wood, of shield and scroll, Hung higher, with a neat âcane fishing-poleâ And careful tackleâall securely out Of reach of children, rummaging about. Beside the woodhouse, with broad branches free Yet close above the roof, an apple tree Known as âThe Prince's HarvestââMagic phrase! That was a boy's own tree, in many ways!â Its girth and height meet both for the caress Of his bare legs and his ambitiousness: And then its apples, humoring his whim, Seemed just to fairly hurry ripe for himâ Even in June, impetuous as he, They dropped to meet him, half-way up the tree. And O their bruised sweet faces where they fell!â And ho! the lips that feigned to âkiss them wellâ! âThe Old Sweet-Apple Tree,â a stalwart, stood In fairly sympathetic neighborhood Of this wild princeling with his early gold To toss about so lavishly nor hold In bounteous hoard to overbrim at once All Nature's lap when came the Autumn months. Under the spacious shade of this the eyes Of swinging children saw swift-changing skies Of blue and green, with sunshine shot between, And when âthe old cat diedâ they saw but green. And, then, there was a cherry tree.âWe all And severally will yet recall From our lost youth, in gentlest memory, The blessed factâThere was a cherry tree. There was a cherry tree. Its bloomy snows Cool even now the fevered sight that knows No more its airy visions of pure joyâ As when you were a boy. There was a cherry tree. The Bluejay set His blue against its whiteâO blue as jet He seemed there then!âBut nowâWhoever knew He was so pale a blue! There was a cherry treeâOur child-eyes saw The miracle:âIts pure-white snows did thaw Into a crimson fruitage, far too sweet But for a boy to eat. There was a cherry tree, give thanks and joy!â There was a bloom of snowâThere was a boyâ There was a Bluejay of the realest blueâ And fruit for both of you. Then the old garden, with the apple trees Grouped round the margin, and âa stand of beesâ By the âwhite-winter-pearmainâ; and a row Of currant-bushes; and a quince or so. The old grape-arbor in the center, by The pathway to the stable, with the sty Behind it, and upon it, cootering flocks Of pigeons,âand the cutest âmartin-boxâ!â Made like a sure-enough houseâwith roof, and doors And windows in it, and veranda-floors And balusters all round itâyes, and at Each end a chimneyâpainted red at that And penciled white, to look like little bricks; And, to cap all the builder's cunning tricks, Two tiny little lightning-rods were run Straight up their sides, and twinkled in the sun. Who built it? Nay, no answer but a smile.â It may be you can guess who, after while. Home in his stall, âOld Sorrelâ munched his hay And oats and corn, and switched the flies away, In a repose of patience good to see, And earnest of the gentlest pedigree. With half-pathetic eye sometimes he gazed Upon the gambols of a colt that grazed Around the edges of the lot outside, And kicked at nothing suddenly, and tried To act grown-up and graceful and high-bred, But dropped, k'whop! and scraped the buggy-shed, Leaving a tuft of woolly, foxy hair Under the sharp end of a gate-hinge there. Then, all ignobly scrambling to his feet And whinnying a whinny like a bleat, He would pursue himself around the lot Andâdo the whole thing over, like as not! ... Ah! what a life of constant fear and dread And flop and squawk and flight the chickens led! Above the fences, either side, were seen The neighbor-houses, set in plots of green Dooryards and greener gardens, tree and wall Alike whitewashed, an order in it all: The scythe hooked in the tree-fork; and the spade And hoe and rake and shovel all, when laid Aside, were in their places, ready for The hand of either the possessor or Of any neighbor, welcome to the loan Of any tool he might not chance to own. THE OLD HOME-FOLKS Such was the Child-World of the long agoâ The little world these children used to know:â Johnty, the oldest, and the best, perhaps, Of the five happy little Hoosier chaps Inhabiting this wee world all their own.â Johnty, the leader, with his native tone Of grave commandâa general on parade Whose each punctilious order was obeyed By his proud followers. But Johnty yetâ After all serious dutiesâcould forget The gravity of life to the extent, At times, of kindling much astonishment About him: With a quick, observant eye, And mind and memory, he could supply The tamest incident with liveliest mirth; And at the most unlooked-for times on earth Was wont to break into some travesty On those around himâfeats of mimicry Of this one's trick of gestureâthat one's walkâ Or this one's laughâor that one's funny talk,â The way âthe watermelon-manâ would try His humor on town-folks that wouldn't buy;â How he drove into town at morningâthen At dusk (alas!) how he drove out again. Though these divertisements of Johnty's were Hailed with a hearty glee and relish, there Appeared a sense, on his part, of regretâ A spirit of remorse that would not let Him rest for days thereafter.âSuch times he, As some boy said, âjist got too overly Blame' good fer common boys like us, you know To 'sociate withâ'less'n we 'ud go And jine his church!â Next after Johnty came His little towhead brother, Bud by name.â And O how white his hair wasâand how thick His face with freckles,âand his ears, how quick And curious and intrusive!âAnd how pale The blue of his big eyes;âand how a tale Of Giants, Trolls or Fairies, bulged them still Bigger and bigger!âAnd when âJackâ would kill The old âFour-headed Giant,â Bud's big eyes Were swollen truly into giant-size. And Bud was apt in make-believesâwould hear His Grandma talk or read, with such an ear And memory of both subject and big words, That he would take the book up afterwards And feign to âread aloud,â with such success As caused his truthful elders real distress. But he must have big wordsâthey seemed to give Extremer range to the superlativeâ That was his passion. âMy Gran'ma,â he said, One evening, after listening as she read Some heavy old historical reviewâ With copious explanations thereunto Drawn out by his inquiring turn of mind,â âMy Gran'ma she's read all booksâever' kind They is, 'at tells all 'bout the land an' sea An' Nations of the Earth!âAn' she is the Historicul-est woman ever wuz!â (Forgive the verse's chuckling as it does In its erratic current.âOftentimes The little willowy water-brook of rhymes Must falter in its music, listening to The children laughing as they used to do.) Who shall sing a simple ditty all about the Willow, Dainty-fine and delicate as any bending spray That dandles high the happy bird that flutters there to trill a Tremulously tender song of greeting to the May. Bravest, too, of all the trees!ânone to match your daring,â First of greens to greet the Spring and lead in leafy sheen;â Ay, and you're the lastâalmost into winter wearing Still the leaf of loyaltyâstill the badge of green. Ah, my lovely Willow!âLet the Waters lilt your graces,â They alone with limpid kisses lave your leaves above, Flashing back your sylvan beauty, and in shady places Peering up with glimmering pebbles, like the eyes of love. Next, Maymie, with her hazy cloud of hair, And the blue skies of eyes beneath it there. Her dignified and âlittle ladyâ airs Of never either romping up the stairs Or falling down them; thoughtful every way Of others firstâThe kind of child at play That âgave up,â for the rest, the ripest pear Or peach or apple in the garden there Beneath the trees where swooped the airy swingâ She pushing it, too glad for anything! Or, in the character of hostess, she Would entertain her friends delightfully In her playhouse,âwith strips of carpet laid Along the garden-fence within the shade Of the old apple treesâwhere from next yard Came the two dearest friends in her regard, The little Crawford girls, Ella and Luâ As shy and lovely as the lilies grew In their idyllic home,âyet sometimes they Admitted Bud and Alex to their play, Who did their heavier work and helped them fix To have a âFestibulââand brought the bricks And built the âstove,â with a real fire and all, And stovepipe-joint for chimney, looming tall And wonderfully smokyâeven to Their childish aspirations, as it blew And swooped and swirled about them till their sight Was feverish even as their high delight. Then Alex, with his freckles, and his freaks Of temper, and the peach-bloom of his cheeks, And âamber-colored hairââhis mother said 'Twas that, when others laughed and called it âredâ And Alex threw things at themâtill they'd call A truce, agreeing â't'uzn't red ut-tall!â But Alex was affectionate beyond The average child, and was extremely fond Of the paternal relatives of his, Of whom he once made estimate like this:â âI'm only got two brothers,âbut my Pa He's got most brothers'n you ever saw!â He's got seben brothers!âYes, an' they're all my Seben Uncles!âUncle John, an' Jim,âan' I Got Uncle George, an' Uncle Andy, too, An' Uncle Frank, an' Uncle Joe.âAn' you Know Uncle Mart.âAn', all but him, they're great Big mens!âAn' nen's Aunt Sarahâshe makes eight!â I'm got eight uncles!â'cept Aunt Sarah can't Be ist my uncle 'cause she's ist my a'nt!â Then, next to Alexâand the last indeed Of these five little ones of whom you readâ Was baby Lizzie, with her velvet lisp,â As though her elfin lips had caught some wisp Of floss between them as they strove with speech, Which ever seemed just in, yet out of, reachâ Though what her lips missed, her dark eyes could say With looks that made her meaning clear as day. And, knowing now the children, you must know The father and the mother they loved so:â The father was a swarthy man, black-eyed, Black-haired, and high of forehead; and, beside The slender little mother, seemed in truth A very king of menâsince, from his youth, To his hale manhood nowâ(worthy as then,â A lawyer and a leading citizen Of the proud little town and county-seatâ His hopes his neighbors', and their fealty sweet)â He had known outdoor laborârain and shineâ Bleak Winter, and bland Summerâfoul and fine. So Nature had ennobled him and set Her symbol on him like a coronet: His lifted brow, and frank, reliant faceâ Superior of stature as of grace,â Even the children by the spell were wrought Up to heroics of their simple thought, And saw him, trim of build, and lithe and straight And tall, almost, as at the pasture-gate The towering ironweed the scythe had spared For their sakes, when The Hired Man declared It would grow on till it became a tree, With cocoanuts and monkeys inâmaybe! Yet, though the children, in their pride and awe And admiration of the father, saw A being so exaltedâeven more Like adoration was the love they bore The gentle mother.âHer mild, plaintive face Was purely fair, and haloed with a grace And sweetness luminous when joy made glad Her features with a smile; or saintly sad As twilight, fell the sympathetic gloom Of any childish grief, or as a room Were darkened suddenly, the curtain drawn Across the window and the sunshine gone. Her brow, below her fair hair's glimmering strands, Seemed meetest resting-place for blessing hands Or holiest touches of soft finger-tips And little rose-leaf cheeks and dewy lips. Though heavy household tasks were pitiless, No little waist or coat or checkered dress But knew her needle's deftness; and no skill Matched hers in shaping plait or flounce or frill; Or fashioning, in complicate design, All rich embroideries of leaf and vine, With tiniest twining tendril,âbud and bloom And fruit, so like, one's fancy caught perfume And dainty touch and taste of them, to see Their semblance wrought in such rare verity. Shrined in her sanctity of home and love, And love's fond service and reward thereof, Restore her thus, O blessed Memory!â Throned in her rocking-chair, and on her knee Her sewingâher work-basket on the floor Beside her,âSpring-time through the open door Balmily stealing in and all about The room; the bees' dim hum, and the far shout And laughter of the children at their play, And neighbor children from across the way Calling in gleeful challengeâsave alone One boy whose voice sends back no answering toneâ The boy, prone on the floor, above a book Of pictures, with a rapt, ecstatic lookâ Even as the mother's, by the selfsame spell, Is lifted, with a light ineffableâ As though her senses caught no mortal cry, But heard, instead, some poem going by. The Child-heart is so strange a little thingâ So mildâso timorously shy and small,â When grown-up hearts throb, it goes scampering Behind the wall, nor dares peer out at all!â It is the veriest mouse That hides in any houseâ So wild a little thing is any Child-heart! Child-heart!âmild heart!â Ho, my little wild heart!â Come up here to me out o' the dark, Or let me come to you! So lorn at times the Child-heart needs must be, With never one maturer heart for friend And comrade, whose tear-ripened sympathy And love might lend it comfort to the end,â Whose yearnings, aches and stings, Over poor little things Were pitiful as ever any Child-heart. Child-heart!âmild heart!â Ho, my little wild heart!â Come up here to me out o' the dark, Or let me come to you! Times, too, the little Child-heart must be gladâ Being so young, nor knowing, as we know, The fact from fantasy, the good from bad, The joy from woe, theâall that hurts us so! What wonder then that thus It hides away from us?â So weak a little thing is any Child-heart! Child-heart!âmild heart!â Ho, my little wild heart!â Come up here to me out o' the dark, Or let me come to you! Nay, little Child-heart, you have never need To fear us;âwe are weaker far than youâ 'Tis we who should be fearfulâwe indeed Should hide us, too, as darkly as you do,â Safe, as yourself, withdrawn, Hearing the World roar on Too wilful, woeful, awful for the Child-heart! Child-heart!âmild heart!â Ho, my little wild heart!â Come up here to me out o' the dark, Or let me come to you! The clock chats on confidingly; a rose Taps at the window, as the sunlight throws A brilliant, jostling checkerwork of shine And shadow, like a Persian-loom design, Across the home-made carpetâfades,âand then The dear old colors are themselves again. Sounds drop in visiting from everywhereâ The bluebird's and the robin's trill are there, Their sweet liquidity diluted some By dewy orchard-spaces they have come: Sounds of the town, too, and the great highwayâ The Mover-wagons' rumble, and the neigh Of over-traveled horses, and the bleat Of sheep and low of cattle through the streetâ A Nation's thoroughfare of hopes and fears, First blazed by the heroic pioneers Who gave up old-home idols and set face Toward the unbroken West, to found a race And tame a wilderness now mightier than All peoples and all tracts American. Blent with all outer sounds, the sounds within:â In mild remoteness falls the household din Of porch and kitchen: the dull jar and thump Of churning; and the âglung-glungâ of the pump, With sudden pad and skurry of bare feet Of little outlaws, in from field or street: The clang of kettle,ârasp of damper-ring And bang of cook-stove doorâand everything That jingles in a busy kitchen lifts Its individual wrangling voice and drifts In sweetest tinny, coppery, pewtery tone Of music hungry ear has ever known In wildest famished yearning and conceit Of youth, to just cut loose and eat and eat!â The zest of hunger still incited on To childish desperation by long-drawn Breaths of hot, steaming, wholesome things that stew And blubber, and uptilt the pot-lids, too, Filling the sense with zestful rumors of The dear old-fashioned dinners children love: Redolent savorings of home-cured meats, Potatoes, beans and cabbage; turnips, beets And parsnipsârarest composite entire That ever pushed a mortal child's desire To madness by new-grated fresh, keen, sharp Horseradishâtang that sets the lips awarp And watery, anticipating all The cloyed sweets of the glorious festival.â Still add the cinnamony, spicy scents Of clove, nutmeg, and myriad condiments In like-alluring whiffs that prophesy Of sweltering pudding, cake, and custard-pieâ The swooning-sweet aroma haunting all The houseâup-stairs and downâporch, parlor, hall And sitting-roomâinvading even where The Hired Man sniffs it in the orchard-air, And pauses in his pruning of the trees To note the sun minutely and toâsneeze. Then Cousin Rufus comesâthe children hear His hale voice in the old hall, ringing clear As any bell. Always he came with song Upon his lips and all the happy throng Of echoes following him, even as the crowd Of his admiring little kinsmenâproud To have a cousin grownâand yet as young Of soul and cheery as the songs he sung. He was a student of the lawâintent Soundly to win success, with all it meant; And so he studiedâeven as he played,â With all his heart: And so it was he made His gallant fight for fortuneâthrough all stress Of battle bearing him with cheeriness And wholesome valor. And the children had Another relative who kept them glad And joyous by his very merry waysâ As blithe and sunny as the summer days,â Their father's youngest brotherâUncle Mart. The old âArabian Nightsâ he knew by heartâ âBaron Munchausen,â too; and likewise âThe Swiss Family Robinson.ââAnd when these three Gave out, as he rehearsed them, he could go Straight on in the same lineâa steady flow Of arabesque invention that his good Old mother never clearly understood. He was to be a printerâwanted, though, To be an actor.âBut the world was âshowâ Enough for him,âtheatric, airy, gay,â Each day to him was jolly as a play. And some poetic symptoms, too, in sooth, Were certain.âAnd, from his apprentice youth, He joyed in verse-quotationsâwhich he took Out of the old âType Foundry Specimen Book.â He craved and courted most the favor of The children.âThey were foremost in his love; And pleasing them, he pleased his own boy-heart And kept it young and fresh in every part. So was it he devised for them and wrought To life his quaintest, most romantic thought:â Like some lone castaway in alien seas, He built a house up in the apple trees, Out in the corner of the garden, where No man-devouring native, prowling there, Might pounce upon them in the dead o' nightâ For lo, their little ladder, slim and light, They drew up after them. And it was known That Uncle Mart slipped up sometimes alone And drew the ladder in, to lie and moon Over some novel all the afternoon. And one time Johnty, from the crowd below,â Outraged to find themselves deserted soâ Threw bodily their old black cat up in The airy fastness, with much yowl and din Resulting, while a wild periphery Of cat went circling to another tree, And, in impassioned outburst, Uncle Mart Loomed up, and thus relieved his tragic heart: ââHence, long-tailed, ebon-eyed, nocturnal ranger! What led thee hither 'mongst the types and cases? Didst thou not know that running midnight races O'er standing types was fraught with imminent danger? Did hunger lead theeâdidst thou think to find Some rich old cheese to fill thy hungry maw? Vain hope! for none but literary jaw Can masticate our cookery for the mind!ââ So likewise when, with lordly air and grace, He strode to dinner, with a tragic face With ink-spots on it from the office, he Would aptly quote more âSpecimen-poetryââ Perchance like ââLabor's bread is sweet to eat, (Ahem!) And toothsome is the toiler's meat.ââ Ah, could you see them all, at lull of noon!â A sort of boisterous lull, with clink of spoon And clatter of deflecting knife, and plate Dropped saggingly, with its all-bounteous weight, And dragged in place voraciously; and then Pent exclamations, and the lull again.â The garland of glad faces round the boardâ Each member of the family restored To his or her place, with an extra chair Or two for the chance guests so often there.â The father's farmer-client, brought home from The court room, though he âdidn't want to come Tel he jist saw he hat to!â he'd explain, Invariably, time and time again, To the pleased wife and hostess, as she pressed Another cup of coffee on the guest.â Or there was Johnty's special chum, perchance, Or Bud's, or bothâeach childish countenance Lit with a higher glow of youthful glee, To be together thus unbrokenly,â Jim Offutt, or Eck Skinner, or George Carrâ The very nearest chums of Bud's these are,â So, very probably, one of the three, At least, is there with Bud, or ought to be. Like interchange the town-boys each had knownâ His playmate's dinner better than his ownâ Yet blest that he was ever made to stay At Almon Keefer's, any blessed day, For any meal! ... Visions of biscuits, hot And flaky-perfect, with the golden blot Of molten butter for the center, clear, Through pools of clover-honeyâdear-o-dear!â With creamy milk for its divine âfarewellâ: And then, if any one delectable Might yet exceed in sweetness, O restore The cherry-cobbler of the days of yore Made only by Al Keefer's mother!âWhy, The very thought of it ignites the eye Of memory with raptureâcloys the lip Of longing, till it seems to ooze and drip With veriest juice and stain and overwaste Of that most sweet delirium of taste That ever visited the childish tongue, Or proved, as now, the sweetest thing unsung. Ah, Almon Keefer! what a boy you were, With your back-tilted hat and careless hair, And open, honest, fresh, fair face and eyes With their all-varying looks of pleased surprise And joyous interest in flower and tree, And poising humming-bird, and maundering bee. The fields and woods he knew; the tireless tramp With gun and dog; and the night-fisher's campâ No other boy, save Bee Lineback, had won Such brilliant mastery of rod and gun. Even in his earliest childhood had he shown These traits that marked him as his father's own. Dogs all paid Almon honor and bow-wowed Allegiance, let him come in any crowd Of rabbit-hunting town-boys, even though His own dog âSleuthâ rebuked their acting so With jealous snarls and growlings. But the best Of Almon's virtuesâleading all the restâ Was his great love of books, and skill as well In reading them aloud, and by the spell Thereof enthralling his mute listeners, as They grouped about him in the orchard-grass, Hinging their bare shins in the mottled shine And shade, as they lay prone, or stretched supine Beneath their favorite tree, with dreamy eyes And Argo-fancies voyaging the skies. âTales of the Oceanâ was the name of one Old dog's-eared book that was surpassed by none Of all the glorious list.âIts back was gone, But its vitality went bravely on In such delicious tales of land and sea As may not ever perish utterly. Of still more dubious caste, âJack Sheppardâ drew Full admiration; and âDick Turpin,â too. And, painful as the fact is to convey, In certain lurid tales of their own day, These boys found thieving heroes and outlaws They hailed with equal fervor of applause: âThe League of the Miamiââwhy, the name Alone was fascinatingâis the same, In memory, this venerable hour Of moral wisdom shorn of all its power, As it unblushingly reverts to when The old barn was âthe Cave,â and hears again The signal blown, outside the buggy-shedâ The drowsy guard within uplifts his head, And ââWho goes there?ââ is called, in bated breathâ The challenge answered in a hush of death,â âSh!ââBarney Gray!ââ And then ââWhat do you seek?ââ ââStables of The League!ââ the voice comes spent and weak, For, ha! the Law is on the âChieftain'sâ trailâ Tracked to his very lair!âWell, what avail? The âsecret entranceâ opensâcloses.âSo The âRobber-Captainâ thus outwits his foe; And, safe once more within his âcavern-halls,â He shakes his clenched fist at the warped plankwalls And mutters his defiance through the cracks At the balked Enemy's retreating backs As the loud horde flees pell-mell down the lane, AndâAlmon Keefer is himself again! Excepting few, they were not books indeed Of deep import that Almon chose to read;â Less fact than fiction.âMuch he favored thoseâ If not in poetry, in hectic proseâ That made our native Indian a wild, Feathered and fine-preened hero that a child Could recommend as just about the thing To make a god of, or at least a king. Aside from Almon's own booksâtwo or threeâ His store of lore The Township Library Supplied him weekly: All the books with âor'sâ Subtitledâlured himâafter âIndian Wars,â And âLife of Daniel Boone,âânot to include Some few books spiced with humor,ââRobin Hoodâ And rare âDon Quixote.ââAnd one time he took âDadd's Cattle Doctor.â ... How he hugged the book And hurried homeward, with internal glee And humorous spasms of expectancy!â All this confessionâas he promptly made It, the day later, writhing in the shade Of the old apple tree with Johnty and Bud, Noey Bixler, and The Hired Handâ Was quite as funny as the book was not. ... O Wonderland of wayward Childhood! what An easy, breezy realm of summer calm And dreamy gleam and gloom and bloom and balm Thou art!âThe Lotus-Land the poet sung, It is the Child-World while the heart beats young. ... While the heart beats young!âO the splendor of the Spring, With all her dewy jewels on, is not so fair a thing! The fairest, rarest morning of the blossom-time of May Is not so sweet a season as the season of to-day While Youth's diviner climate folds and holds us, close caressed As we feel our mothers with us by the touch of face and breast;â Our bare feet in the meadows, and our fancies up among The airy clouds of morningâwhile the heart beats young. While the heart beats young and our pulses leap and dance, With every day a holiday and life a glad romance,â We hear the birds with wonder, and with wonder watch their flightâ Standing still the more enchanted, both of hearing and of sight, When they have vanished wholly,âfor, in fancy, wing-to-wing We fly to Heaven with them; and, returning, still we sing The praises of this lower Heaven with tireless voice and tongue, Even as the Master sanctionsâwhile the heart beats young. While the heart beats young!âWhile the heart beats young! O green and gold old Earth of ours, with azure overhung And looped with rainbows!âgrant us yet this grassy lap of thineâ We would be still thy children, through the shower and the shine! So pray we, lisping, whispering, in childish love and trust, With our beseeching hands and faces lifted from the dust By fervor of the poem, all unwritten and unsung, Thou givest us in answer, while the heart beats young. Another hero of those youthful years Returns, as Noey Bixler's name appears. And Noeyâif in any special wayâ Was notably good-natured.âWork or play He entered into with selfsame delightâ A wholesome interest that made him quite As many friends among the old as young,â So everywhere were Noey's praises sung. And he was awkward, fat and overgrown, With a round full-moon face, that fairly shone As though to meet the simile's demand. And, cumbrous though he seemed, both eye and hand Were dowered with the discernment and deft skill Of the true artisan: He shaped at will, In his old father's shop, on rainy days, Little toy-wagons, and curved-runner sleighs; The trimmest bows and arrowsâfashioned, too, Of âseasoned timber,â such as Noey knew How to select, prepare, and then complete, And call his little friends in from the street. âThe very best bow,â Noey used to say, âHain't made o' ash ner hick'ry thataway!â But you git mulberryâthe bearin'-tree, Now mind ye! and you fetch the piece to me, And lemme git it seasoned; then, i gum! I'll make a bow 'at you kin brag on some! Erâef you can't git mulberry,âyou bring Me a' old locus' hitch-post, and, i jing! I'll make a bow o' that 'at common bows Won't dast to pick on ner turn up their nose!â And Noey knew the woods, and all the trees And thickets, plants and myriad mysteries Of swamp and bottom-land. And he knew where The ground-hog hid, and why located there.â He knew all animals that burrowed, swam, Or lived in tree-tops: And, by race and dam, He knew the choicest, safest deeps wherein Fish-traps might flourish nor provoke the sin Of theft in some chance peeking, prying sneak, Or town-boy, prowling up and down the creek. All four-pawed creatures tamableâhe knew Their outer and their inner natures too; While they, in turn, were drawn to him as by Some subtle recognition of a tie Of love, as true as truth from end to end, Between themselves and this strange human friend The same with birdsâhe knew them every one And he could âname them, too, without a gun.â No wonder Johnty loved him, even to The verge of worship.âNoey led him through The art of trapping redbirdsâyes, and taught Him how to keep them when he had them caughtâ What food they needed, and just where to swing The cage, if he expected them to sing. And Bud loved Noey, for the little pair Of stilts he made him; or the stout old hair Trunk Noey put on wheels, and laid a track Of scantling-railroad for it in the back Part of the barn-lot; or the crossbow, made Just like a gun, which deadly weapon laid Against his shoulder as he aimed, andââSping!â He'd hear the rusty old nail zoon and singâ And zip! your Mr. Bluejay's wing would drop A farewell-feather from the old tree-top! And Maymie loved him, for the very small But perfect carriage for her favorite dollâ A lady's carriageânot a baby-cab,â But oil-cloth top, and two seats, lined with drab And trimmed with white lace-paper from a case Of shaving-soap his uncle bought some place At auction once. And Alex loved him yet The best, when Noey brought him, for a pet, A little flying-squirrel, with great eyesâ Big as a child's: And, childlike otherwise, It was at first a timid, tremulous, coy, Retiring little thing that dodged the boy And tried to keep in Noey's pocket;âtill, In time responsive to his patient will, It became wholly docile, and content With its new master, as he came and went,â The squirrel clinging flatly to his breast, Or sometimes scampering its craziest Around his body spirally, and then Down to his very heels and up again. And Little Lizzie loved him, as a bee Loves a great ripe red appleâutterly. For Noey's ruddy morning-face she drew The window-blind, and tapped the window, too; Afar she hailed his coming, as she heard His tuneless whistlingâsweet as any bird It seemed to her, the one lame bar or so Of old âWait for the Wagonââhoarse and low The sound was,âso that, all about the place, Folks joked and said that Noey âwhistled bassââ The light remark originally made By Cousin Rufus, who knew notes, and played The flute with nimble skill, and taste as well, And, critical as he was musical, Regarded Noey's constant whistling thus âPhenomenally unmelodious.â Likewise when Uncle Mart, who shared the love Of jest with Cousin Rufus hand-in-glove, Said âNoey couldn't whistle âBonny Doonâ Even! and, he'd bet, couldn't carry a tune If it had handles to it!â âBut forgive The deviations here so fugitive, And turn again to Little Lizzie, whose High estimate of Noey we shall choose Above all others.âAnd to her he was Particularly lovable because He laid the woodland's harvest at her feet.â He brought her wild strawberries, honey-sweet And dewy-cool, in mats of greenest moss And leaves, all woven over and across With tender, biting âtongue-grass,â and âsheep-sour,â And twin-leaved beech-mast, pranked with bud and flower Of every gipsy-blossom of the wild, Dark, tangled forest, dear to any child.â All these in season. Nor could barren, drear, White and stark-featured Winter interfere With Noey's rare resources: Still the same He blithely whistled through the snow and came Beneath the window with a Fairy sled; And Little Lizzie, bundled heels-and-head, He took on such excursions of delight As even âOld Santyâ with his reindeer might Have envied her! And, later, when the snow Was softening toward Spring-time and the glow Of steady sunshine smote upon it,âthen Came the magician Noey yet againâ While all the children were away a day Or two at Grandma's!âand behold when they Got home once more;âthere, towering taller than The doorwayâstood a mighty, old Snow-Man! A thing of peerless artâa masterpiece Doubtless unmatched by even classic Greece In heyday of Praxiteles.âAlone It loomed in lordly grandeur all its own. And steadfast, too, for weeks and weeks it stood, The admiration of the neighborhood As well as of the children Noey sought Only to honor in the work he wrought. The traveler paid it tribute, as he passed Along the highwayâpaused and, turning, cast A lingering, last lookâas though to take A vivid print of it, for memory's sake, To lighten all the empty, aching miles Beyond with brighter fancies, hopes and smiles. The cynic put aside his biting wit And tacitly declared in praise of it; And even the apprentice-poet of the town Rose to impassioned heights, and then sat down And penned a panegyric scroll of rhyme That made the Snow-Man famous for all time. And though, as now, the ever warmer sun Of summer had so melted and undone The perishable figure thatâalas!â Not even in dwindled white against the grass Was left its latest and minutest ghost, The children yetâmaterially, almostâ Beheld itâcircled round it hand-in- handâ (Or rather round the place it used to stand)â With âRing-a-round-a-rosy! Bottle full O' posy!â and, with shriek and laugh, would pull From seeming contact with itâjust as when It was the real-est of old Snow-Men! Even in such a scene of senseless play The children were surprised one summer day By a strange man who called across the fence, Inquiring for their father's residence; And, being answered that this was the place, Opened the gate, and, with a radiant face, Came in and sat down with them in the shade And waitedâtill the absent father made His noon appearance, with a warmth and zest That told he had no ordinary guest In this man whose low-spoken name he knew At once, demurring as the stranger drew A stuffy note-book out, and turned and set A big fat finger on a page, and let The writing thereon testify instead Of further speech. And as the father read All silently, the curious children took Exacting inventory both of book And man:âHe wore a long-napped white fur hat Pulled firmly on his head, and under that Rather long silvery hair, or iron-grayâ For he was not an old man,âanyway, Not beyond sixty. And he wore a pair Of square-framed spectaclesâor rather there Were two more than a pair,âthe extra two Flared at the corners, at the eyes' side-view, In as redundant vision as the eyes Of grasshoppers or bees or dragon-flies. Later the children heard the father say He was âA Noted Traveler,â and would stay Some days with them.âIn which time host and guest Discussed, alone, in deepest interest, Some vague, mysterious matter that defied The wistful children, loitering outside The spare-room door. There Bud acquired a quite New list of big wordsâsuch as âDisunite,â And âShibboleth,â and âAristocracy,â And âJuggernaut,â and âSquatter Sovereignty,â And âAntislavery,â and âEmancipate,â âIrrepressible Conflict,â and âThe Great Battle of Armageddonââobviously A pamphlet brought from Washington, D. C., And spread among such friends as might occur Of like views with âThe Noted Traveler.â A PROSPECTIVE VISIT While any day was notable and dear That gave the children Noey, history here Records his advent emphasized indeed With sharp italics, as he came to feed The stock one special morning, fair and bright, When Johnty and Bud met him, with delight Unusual even as their extra dressâ Garbed as for holiday, with much excess Of proud self-consciousness and vain conceit In their new finery.âFar up the street They called to Noey, as he came, that they, As promised, both were going back that day To his house with him! And by time that each Had one of Noey's handsâceasing their speech And coyly anxious, in their new attire, To wake the comment of their mute desire,â Noey seemed rendered voiceless. Quite a while They watched him furtively.âHe seemed to smile As though he would conceal it; and they saw Him look away, and his lips purse and draw In curious, twitching spasms, as though he might Be whispering,âwhile in his eye the white Predominated strangely.âThen the spell Gave way, and his pent speech burst audible: âThey wuz two stylish little boys, and they wuz mighty bold ones, Had two new pairs o' britches made out o' their Daddy's old ones!â And at the inspirational outbreak, Both joker and his victims seemed to take An equal share of laughter,âand all through Their morning visit kept recurring to The funny words and jingle of the rhyme That just kept getting funnier all the time. When he went I bet you could 'a' bought him fer a cent! âAnd now, behold ye all!âas Tubb and me Wuz 'bout to raise up,âright in front we see A feller slippin' out the arber, square Smack under that-air little winder where The other feller had been standin'.âAnd The thing he wuz a-carryin' in his hand Wuzn't no gun at all!âit wuz a flute,â And whoop-ee! how it did git up and toot And chirp and warble, tel a mockin'-bird 'Ud dast to never let hisse'f be heerd Ferever, after such miracalous, high Jimcracks and grand skyrootics played there by Yer Cousin Rufus!âYes-sir; it wuz him!â And what's more,âall a-suddent that-air dim Dark winder o' Miss Wetherell's wuz lit Up like a' oyshture-sign, and under it We see him sort o' wet his lips and smile Down 'long his row o' dancin' fingers, while He kind o' stiffened up and kinked his breath And everlastin'ly jes' blowed the peth Out o' that-air old one-keyed flute o' his. And, bless their hearts, that's all the âtaleâ they is!â And even as Noey closed, all radiantly The unconscious hero of the history, Returning, met a perfect driving storm Of welcomeâa reception strangely warm And unaccountable, to him, although Most gratifying,âand he told them so. âI only urge,â he said, âmy right to be Enlightened.â And a voice said: âCertainly:â During your absence we agreed that you Should tell us all a story, old or new, Just in the immediate happy frame of mind We knew you would return in.â So, resigned, The ready flutist tossed his hat asideâ Glanced at the children, smiled, and thus complied. COUSIN RUFUS' STORY My little story, Cousin Rufus said, Is not so much a story as a fact. It is about a certain wilful boyâ An aggrieved, unappreciated boy, Grown to dislike his own home very much, By reason of his parents being not At all up to his rigid standard and Requirements and exactions as a son And disciplinarian. So, sullenly He brooded over his disheartening Environments and limitations, till, At last, well knowing that the outside world Would yield him favors never found at home, He rose determinedly one July dawnâ Even before the call for breakfastâand, Climbing the alley-fence, and bitterly Shaking his clenched fist at the wood-pile, he Evanished down the turnpike.âYes: he had, Once and for all, put into execution His long low-muttered threateningsâHe had Run off!âHe hadâhad run away from home! His parents, at discovery of his flight, Bore up first-rateâespecially his Pa,â Quite possibly recalling his own youth, And therefrom predicating, by high noon, The absent one was very probably Disporting his nude self in the delights Of the old swimmin'-hole, some hundred yards Below the slaughter-house, just east of town. The stoic father, too, in his surmise Was accurateâFor, lo! the boy was there! And there, too, he remained throughout the dayâ Save at one starving interval in which He clad his sunburnt shoulders long enough To shy across a wheat-field, shadow-like, And raid a neighboring orchardâbitterly, And with spasmodic twitchings of the lip, Bethinking him how all the other boys Had homes to go to at the dinner-hourâ While heâalas!âhe had no home!âAt least These very words seemed rising mockingly, Until his every thought smacked raw and sour And green and bitter as the apples he In vain essayed to stay his hunger with. Nor did he join the glad shouts when the boys Returned rejuvenated for the long Wet revel of the feverish afternoon.â Yet, bravely, as his comrades splashed and swam And spluttered, in their weltering merriment, He tried to laugh, too,âbut his voice was hoarse And sounded to him like some other boy's. And then he felt a sudden, poking sort Of sickness at the heart, as though some cold And scaly pain were blindly nosing it Down in the dreggy darkness of his breast. The tensioned pucker of his purple lips Grew ever chillier and yet more tenseâ The central hurt of it slow spreading till It did possess the little face entire. And then there grew to be a knuckled knotâ An aching kind of core within his throatâ An ache, all dry and swallowless, which seemed To ache on just as bad when he'd pretend He didn't notice it as when he did. It was a kind of a conceited painâ An overbearing, self-assertive and Barbaric sort of pain that clean outhurt A boy's capacity for sufferingâ So, many times, the little martyr needs Must turn himself all suddenly and dive From sight of his hilarious playmates and Surreptitiously weep under water. Thus He wrestled with his awful agony Till almost dark; and then, at lastâthen, with The very latest lingering group of his Companions, he moved turgidly toward homeâ Nay, rather oozed that way, so slow he went,â With loathful, hesitating, loitering, Reluctant late-election-returns air, Heightened somewhat by the conscience-made resolve Of chopping a double armful of wood As he went in by rear way of the kitchen. And this resolve he executed;âyet The hired girl made no comment whatsoever But went on washing up the supper-things, Crooning the unutterably sad song, âThen think, Oh, think how lonely this heart must ever be!â Still, with affected carelessness, the boy Ranged through the pantry; but the cupboard-door Was locked. He sighed then like a wet forestick And went out on the porch.âAt least the pump, He prophesied, would meet him kindly and Shake hands with him and welcome his return! And long he held the old tin dipper upâ And oh, how fresh and pure and sweet the draught! Over the upturned brim, with grateful eyes He saw the back-yard, in the gathering night, Vague, dim and lonesome; but it all looked good: The lightning-bugs, against the grape-vines, blinked A sort of sallow gladness over his Home-coming, with this softening of the heart. He did not leave the dipper carelessly In the milk-trough.âNo: he hung it back upon Its old nail thoughtfullyâeven tenderly. All slowly then he turned and sauntered toward The rain-barrel at the corner of the house, And, pausing, peered into it at the few Faint stars reflected there. Thenâmoved by some Strange impulse new to himâhe washed his feet. He then went in the houseâstraight on into The very room where sat his parents by The evening lamp.âThe father all intent Reading his paper, and the mother quite As intent with her sewing. Neither looked Up at his entranceâeven reproachfully,â And neither spoke. The wistful runaway Drew a long, quavering breath, and then sat down Upon the extreme edge of a chair. And all Was very still there for a long, long while.â Yet everything, someway, seemed restful-like And homy and old-fashioned, good and kind, And sort of kin to him!âOnly too still! If somebody would say somethingâjust speakâ Or even rise up suddenly and come And lift him by the ear sheer off his chairâ Or box his jawsâLord bless 'em!âanything!â Was he not there to thankfully accept Any reception from parental source Save this incomprehensible voicelessness? O but the silence held its very breath! If but the ticking clock would only strike And for an instant drown the whispering, Lisping, sifting sound the katydids Made outside in the grassy nowhere! Far Down some back street he heard the faint halloo Of boys at their night-game of âTown-fox,â But now with no desire at all to be Participating in their sport.âNo; no;â Never again in this world would he want To join them there!âhe only wanted just To stay in home of nightsâAlwaysâalwaysâ Forever and a day! He moved; and coughedâ Coughed hoarsely, too, through his rolled tongue; and yet No vaguest of parental notice or Solicitude in answerâno responseâ No wordâno look. O it was deathly still!â So still it was that really he could not Remember any prior silence that At all approached it in profundity And depth and density of utter hush. He felt that he himself must break it: So, Summoning every subtle artifice Of seeming nonchalance and native ease And naturalness of utterance to his aid, And gazing raptly at the house-cat where She lay curled in her wonted corner of The hearth-rug, dozing, he spoke airily And said: âI see you've got the same old cat!â BEWILDERING EMOTIONS The merriment that followed was subduedâ As though the story-teller's attitude Were dual, in a sense, appealing quite As much to sorrow as to mere delight, According, haply, to the listener's bent Either of sad or merry temperament.â âAnd of your two appeals I much prefer The pathos,â said âThe Noted Traveler,ââ âFor should I live to twice my present years, I know I could not quite forget the tears That child-eyes bleed, the little palms nailed wide, And quivering soul and body crucified. ... But, bless them! there are no such children here To-night, thank God!âCome here to me, my dear!â He said to little Alex, in a tone So winning that the sound of it alone Had drawn a child more loathful to his knee:â âAnd, now-sir, I'll agree if you'll agree,â You tell us all a story, and then I Will tell one.â âBut I can't.â âWell, can't you try?â âYes, Mister: he kin tell one. Alex, tell The one, you know, 'at you made up so well, About the Bear. He allus tells that one,â Said Bud,ââHe gits it mixed some 'bout the gun An' ax the Little Boy had, an' apples, too.ââ Then Uncle Mart saidââThere, now! that'll do!â Let Alex tell his story his own way!â And Alex, prompted thus, without delay Began. THE PATHOS OF APPLAUSE The greeting of the company throughout Was like a jubilee,âthe children's shout And fusillading hand-claps, with great guns And detonations of the older ones, Raged to such tumult of tempestuous joy, It even more alarmed than pleased the boy; Till, with a sudden twitching lip, he slid Down to the floor and dodged across and hid His face against his mother as she raised Him to the shelter of her heart, and praised His story in low whisperings, and smoothed The âamber-colored hair,â and kissed and soothed And lulled him back to sweet tranquillityâ âAn' 'at's a sign 'at you're the Ma fer me!â He lisped, with gurgling ecstasy, and drew Her closer, with shut eyes; and feeling, too, If he could only purr now like a cat, He would undoubtedly be doing that! âAnd nowââthe serious host said, lifting there A hand entreating silence;âânow, aware Of the good promise of our Traveler guest To add some story with and for the rest, I think I favor you, and him as well, Asking a story I have heard him tell, And know its truth, in each minute detail:â Then leaning on his guest's chair, with a hale Hand-pat by way of full endorsement, he Said, âYesâthe Free-Slave storyâcertainly.â The old man, with his waddy note-book out, And glittering spectacles, glanced round about The expectant circle, and still firmer drew His hat on, with a nervous cough or two: And, save at times the big hard words, and tone Of gathering passionâall the speaker's own,â The tale that set each childish heart astir Was thus told by âThe Noted Traveler.â TOLD BY âTHE NOTED TRAVELERâ. Coming, clean from the Maryland-end Of this great National Road of ours, Through your vast West; with the time to spend, Stopping for days in the main towns, where Every citizen seemed a friend, And friends grew thick as the wayside flowers,â I found no thing that I might narrate More singularly strange or queer Than a thing I found in your sister-State Ohio,âat a river-townâdown here In my note-book: Zanesvilleâsituate On the stream Muskingumâbroad and clear, And navigable, through half the year, North, to Coshocton; south, as far As Marietta.âBut these facts are Not of the story, but the scene Of the simple little tale I mean To tell directlyâfrom this, straight through To the end that is best worth listening to: Eastward of Zanesville, two or three Miles from the town, as our stage drove in, I on the driver's seat, and he Pointing out this and that to me,â On beyond usâamong the restâ A grovy slope, and a fluttering throng Of little children, which he âguessedâ Was a picnic, as we caught their thin High laughter, as we drove along, Clearer and clearer. Then suddenly He turned and asked, with a curious grin, What were my views on Slavery? âWhy?â I asked, in return, with a wary eye. âBecause,â he answered, pointing his whip At a little, whitewashed house and shed On the edge of the road by the grove ahead,â âBecause there are two slaves there,â he saidâ âTwo Black slaves that I've passed each trip For eighteen years.âThough they've been set free, They have been slaves ever since!â said he. And, as our horses slowly drew Nearer the little house in view, All briefly I heard the history Of this little old Negro woman and Her husband, house, and scrap of land; How they were slaves and had been made free By their dying master, years ago In old Virginia; and then had come North here into a free Stateâso, Safe forever, to found a homeâ For themselves alone?âfor they left South there Five strong sons, who had, alas! All been sold ere it came to pass This first old master with his last breath Had freed the parents.â(He went to death Agonized and in dire despair That the poor slave children might not share Their parents' freedom. And wildly then He moaned for pardon and died. Amen!) Thus, with their freedom, and little sum Of money left them, these two had come North, full twenty long years ago; And, settling there, they had hopefully Gone to work, in their simple way, Haulingâgardeningâraising sweet Corn, and pop-corn.âBird and bee In the garden-blooms and the apple tree Singing with them throughout the slow Summer's day, with its dust and heatâ The crops that thirst and the rains that fail; Or in Autumn chill, when the clouds hung low, And hand-made hominy might find sale In the near town-market; or baking pies And cakes, to range in alluring show At the little window, where the eyes Of the Movers' children, driving past, Grew fixed, till the big white wagons drew Into a halt that would sometimes last Even the space of an hour or twoâ As the dusty, thirsty travelers made Their noonings there in the beeches' shade By the old black Aunty's spring-house, where, Along with its cooling draughts, were found Jugs of her famous sweet spruce-beer, Served with her gingerbread horses there, While Aunty's snow-white cap bobbed round Till the children's rapture knew no bound, As she sang and danced for them, quavering clear And high the chant of her old slave-daysâ âOh, Lo'd, Jinny! my toes is so', Dancin' on yo' sandy flo'!â Even so had they wrought all ways To earn the pennies, and hoard them, too,â And with what ultimate end in view?â They were saving up money enough to be Able, in time, to buy their own Five children back. Ah! the toil gone through! And the long delays and the heartaches, too, And self-denials that they had known! But the pride and glory that was theirs When they first hitched up their shackly cart For the long, long journey South!âThe start In the first drear light of the chilly dawn, With no friends gathered in grieving throng,â With no farewells and favoring prayers; But, as they creaked and jolted on, Their chiming voices broke in songâ ââHail, all hail! don't you see the stars a-fallin'? Hail, all hail! I'm on my way. Gideon am A healin' ba'mâ I belong to the blood-washed army. Gideon am A healin' ba'mâ On my way!ââ And their return!âwith their oldest boy Along with them! Why, their happiness Spread abroad till it grew a joy UniversalâIt even reached And thrilled the town till the Church was stirred Into suspecting that wrong was wrong!â And it stayed awake as the preacher preached A Real âLoveâ-text that he had not long To ransack for in the Holy Word. And the son, restored, and welcomed so, Found service readily in the town; And, with the parents, sure and slow, He went âsaltin' de cole cash down.â So with the next boyâand each one In turn, till four of the five at last Had been brought back; and, in each case, With steady work and good homes not Far from the parents, they chipped in To the family fund, with an equal grace. Thus they managed and planned and wrought, And the old folks throveâTill the night before They were to start for the lone last son In the rainy dawnâtheir money fast Hid away in the house,âtwo mean, Murderous robbers burst the door. ... Then, in the dark, was a scuffleâa fallâ An old man's gasping cryâand then A woman's fife-like shriek. ... Three men Splashing by on horseback heard The summons: And in an instant all Sprang to their duty, with scarce a word. And they were in timeânot only to save The lives of the old folks, but to bag Both the robbers, and buck-and-gag And land them safe in the county jailâ Or, as Aunty said, with a blended awe And subtlety,ââSafe in de calaboose whah De dawgs cain't bite 'em!â âSo prevail The faithful!âSo had the Lord upheld His servants of both deed and prayer,â His the glory unparalleledâ Theirs the reward,âtheir every son Free, at last, as the parents were! And, as the driver ended there In front of the little house, I said, All fervently, âWell done! well done!â At which he smiled, and turned his head, And pulled on the leader's lines, andââSee!â He said,ââyou can read old Aunty's sign?â And, peering down through these specs of mine On a little, square board-sign, I read: âStop, traveler, if you think it fit, And quench your thirst, for a-fi'-penny-bit.â The rocky spring is very clear, And soon converted into beer.â And, though I read aloud, I could Scarce hear myself for laugh and shout Of childrenâa glad multitude Of little people, swarming out Of the picnic-grounds I spoke about.â And in their rapturous midst, I see Againâthrough mists of memoryâ An old black Negress laughing up At the driver, with her broad lips rolled Back from her teeth, chalk-white, and gums Redder than reddest red-ripe plums. He took from her hand the lifted cup Of clear spring-water, pure and cold, And passed it to me: And I raised my hat And drank to her with a reverence that My conscience knew was justly due The old black face, and the old eyes, tooâ The old black head, with its mossy mat Of hair, set under its cap and frills White as the snows on Alpine hills; Drank to the old black smile, but yet Bright as the sun on the violet,â Drank to the gnarled and knuckled old Black hands whose palms had ached and bled And pitilessly been worn pale And white almost as the palms that hold Slavery's lash while the victim's wail Fails as a crippled prayer might fail.â Ay, with a reverence infinite, I drank to the old black face and headâ The old black breast with its life of lightâ The old black hide with its heart of gold. HEAT-LIGHTNING There was a curious quiet for a space Directly following: and in the face Of one rapt listener pulsed the flush and glow Of the heat-lightning that pent passions throw Long ere the crash of speech.âHe broke the spellâ The host:âThe Traveler's story, told so well, He said, had wakened there within his breast A yearning, as it were, to know the restâ That all unwritten sequence that the Lord Of Righteousness must write with flame and sword, Some awful session of His patient thought. Just then it was, his good old mother caught His blazing eyeâso that its fire became But as an emberâthough it burned the same. It seemed to her, she said, that she had heard It was the Heavenly Parent never erred, And not the earthly one that had such grace: âTherefore, my son,â she said, with lifted face And eyes, âlet no one dare anticipate The Lord's intent. While He waits, we will wait.â And with a gust of reverence genuine Then Uncle Mart was aptly ringing inâ ââIf the darkened heavens lower, Wrap thy cloak around thy form; Though the tempest rise in power, God is mightier than the storm!ââ Which utterance reached the restive children all As something humorous. And then a call For him to tell a story, or to âsay A funny piece.â His face fell right away: He knew no story worthy. Then he must Declaim for them: In that, he could not trust His memory. And then a happy thought Struck some one, who reached in his vest and brought Some scrappy clippings into light and said There was a poem of Uncle Mart's he read Last April in âThe Sentinel.â He had It there in print, and knew all would be glad To hear it rendered by the author. And, All reasons for declining at command Exhausted, the now helpless poet rose And said: âI am discovered, I suppose. Ay, even thenâO timely hour!âthe High Gods did confer In our behalf:âAnd, clothed in power, lo, came their Courierâ Not winged with flame nor shod with wind,âbut ambling down the pike, Horseback, with saddle-bags behind, and guise all human-like. In strange lands were your latest honors wonâ In strange wilds, with strange dangers all beset; With rain, like tears, the face of day was wet, As rang the ambushed foeman's fateful gun: And as you felt your final duty done, We feel that glory thrills your spirit yet,â When at the front, in swiftest death, you met The patriot's doom and best reward in one. And so the tumult of that island war, At last, for you, is stilled forevermoreâ Its scenes of blood blend white as ocean foam On your rapt vision as you sight afar The sails of peace, and from that alien shore The proud ship bears you on your voyage home. Or rough or smooth the wave, or lowering day Or starlit skyâyou hold, by native right, Your high tranquillityâthe silent might Of the true heroâso you led the way To victory through stormiest battle-fray, Because your followers, high above the fight, Heard your soul's lightest whisper bid them smite For God and man and space to kneel and pray. And, Father, give us first to comprehend, No ill can come from Thee; lean Thou and lend Us clearer sight to see Our boundless debt to Thee, Since all thy deeds are blessings, in the end. WILLIAM PINKNEY FISHBACK Say first he loved the dear home-hearts, and then He loved his honest fellow citizenâ He loved and honored him, in any post Of duty where he served mankind the most. All that he asked of him in humblest need Was but to find him striving to succeed; All that he asked of him in highest place Was justice to the lowliest of his race. When he found these conditions, proved and tried, He owned he marveled, but was satisfiedâ Relaxed in vigilance enough to smile And, with his own wit, flay himself a while. Often he liked real angerâas, perchance, The summer skies like storm-clouds and the glance Of lightningâfor the clearer, purer blue Of heaven, and the greener old earth, too. All easy things to do he did with care, Knowing the very common danger there; In noblest conquest of supreme debate The facts are simple as the victory great. That which had been a task to hardiest minds To him was a pleasure, such as finds The captive-truant, doomed to read throughout The one lone book he really cares about. Study revived him: Howsoever dim And deep the problem, 'twas a joy to him To solve it wholly; and he seemed as one Refreshed and rested as the work was done. And he had gathered, from all wealth of lore That time has written, such a treasure-store, His mind held opulenceâhis speech the rare Fair grace of sharing all his riches thereâ Sharing with all, but with the greatest zest Sharing with those who seemed the neediest; The young he ever favored; and through these Shall he live longest in men's memories. JOHN CLARK RIDPATH To the lorn ones who loved him first and best, And knew his dear love at its tenderest, We seem akinâwe simplest friends who knew His fellowship, of heart and spirit too: We who have known the happy summertide Of his ingenuous nature, glorified With the inspiring smile that ever lit The earnest face and kindly strength of it: His presence, all-commanding, as his thought Into unconscious eloquence was wrought Until the utterance became a spell That awed us as a spoken miracle. Learning, to him was nativeâwas, in truth, The earliest playmate of his lisping youth, Likewise throughout a life of toil and stress, It was as laughter, health and happiness: And so he played with itâjoyed at its callâ Ran rioting with it, forgetting all Delights of childhood, and of age and fame,â A devotee of learning, still the same! In fancy, even now we catch the glance Of the rapt eye and radiant countenance, As when his discourse, like a woodland's stream, Flowed musically on from theme to theme: The skies, the stars, the mountains and the sea, He worshiped as their high divinityâ Nor did his reverent spirit find one thing On earth too lowly for his worshiping. The weed, the rose, the wildwood or the plain, The teeming harvest, or the blighted grain,â Allâall were fashioned beautiful and good, As the soul saw and senses understood. Thus broadly based, his spacious faith and love Enfolded all below as all aboveâ Nay, ev'n if overmuch he loved mankind, He gave his love's vast largess as designed. Therefore, in fondest, faithful service, he Wrought ever bravely for humanityâ Stood, first of heroes for the Right alliedâ Foes, even, grieving, when (for them) he died. Holstein Turn through his life, each word and deed Now sacred as it isâ How helped and soothed we are to read A history like his! Read Robert Louis Stevenson, And hum these lines of his:â âThe eternal dawn, beyond a doubt, Shall break on hill and plain And put all stars and candles out Ere we be young again.â THE SOLDIER THE DEDICATION OF THE SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' MONUMENT, INDIANAPOLIS, MAY 15, 1902 The Soldier!âmeek the title, yet divine: Therefore, with reverence, as with wild acclaim, We fain would honor in exalted line The glorious lineage of the glorious name: The Soldier.âLo, he ever was and is, Our Country's high custodian, by right Of patriot blood that brims that heart of his With fiercest love, yet honor infinite. The Soldier!âWhy, the very utterance Is musicâas of rallying bugles, blent With blur of drums and cymbals and the chants Of battle-hymns that shake the continent!â The thunder-chorus of a world is stirred To awful, universal jubilee,â Yet ever through it, pure and sweet, are heard The prayers of Womanhood, and Infancy. Even as a fateful tempest sudden loosed Upon our senses, so our thoughts are blown Back where The Soldier battled, nor refused A grave all nameless in a clime unknown.â The Soldierâthough, perchance, worn, old and gray; The Soldierâthough, perchance, the merest lad,â The Soldierâthough he gave his life away, Hearing the shout of âVictory,â was glad; Ay, glad and grateful, that in such a cause His veins were drained at Freedom's holy shrineâ Rechristening the landâas first it was,â His blood poured thus in sacramental sign Of new baptism of the hallowed name âMy Countryâânow on every lip once more And blest of God with still enduring fame.â This thought even then The Soldier gloried o'er. The dying eyes upraised in rapture there,â As, haply, he remembered how a breeze Once swept his boyish brow and tossed his hair, Under the fresh bloom of the orchard-treesâ When his heart hurried, in some wistful haste Of ecstasy, and his quick breath was wild And balmy-sharp and chilly-sweet to taste,â And he towered godlike, though a trembling child! Again, through luminous mists, he saw the skies' Far fields white-tented; and in gray and blue And dazzling gold, he saw vast armies rise And fuse in fireâfrom which, in swiftest view, The Old Flag soared, and friend and foe as one Blent in an instant's vivid mirage. ... Then The eyes closed smiling on the smiling sun That changed the seer to a child again.â And, even so, The Soldier slept.âOur own!â The Soldier of our plaudits, flowers and tears,â O this memorial of bronze and stoneâ His love shall outlast this a thousand years! Yet, as the towering symbol bids us do,â With soul saluting, as salutes the hand, We answer as The Soldier answered to The Captain's high command. NO BOY KNOWS There are many things that boys may knowâ Why this and that are thus and so,â Who made the world in the dark and lit The great sun up to lighten it: Boys know new things every dayâ When they study, or when they play,â When they idle, or sow and reapâ But no boy knows when he goes to sleep. Boys who listenâor should, at least,â May know that the round old earth rolls East;â And know that the ice and the snow and the rainâ Ever repeating their parts againâ Are all just water the sunbeams first Sip from the earth in their endless thirst, And pour again till the low streams leap.â But no boy knows when he goes to sleep. A boy may know what a long, glad while It has been to him since the dawn's first smile, When forth he fared in the realm divine Of brook-laced woodland and spun-sunshine;â He may know each call of his truant mates, And the paths they went,âand the pasture-gates Of the 'cross-lots home through the dusk so deep.â But no boy knows when he goes to sleep. O I have followed me, o'er and o'er, From the flagrant drowse on the parlor-floor, To the pleading voice of the mother when I even doubted I heard it thenâ To the sense of a kiss, and a moonlit room, And dewy odors of locust-bloomâ A sweet white cotâand a cricket's cheep.â But no boy knows when he goes to sleep. 'Cause it wuz her old Ma an' Pa 'At hate' my Pa, an' toss their head, An' ist raise Ned! An' her Pa said He'd ruther see his daughter dead! Spread and read again with me The Book of Joyous Children. What a whir of wings, and what Sudden drench of dews upon The young brows, wreathed, all unsought, With the apple-blossom garlands Of the poets of those far lands Whence all dreams are drawn Set herein and soiling not The Book of Joyous Children. In their blithe companionship Taste again, these pages through, The hot honey on your lip Of the sun-smit wild strawberry, Or the chill tart of the cherry; Kneel, all glowing, to The cool spring, and with it sip The Book of Joyous Children. DAVENPORT Wess he says, and sort o' grins, âArt and Poetry is twins! âYit, if I'd my pick, I'd shake Poetry, and no mistake! âPictures, allus 'peared to me, Clean laid over Poetry! âLet me draw, and then, i jings, I'll not keer a straw who sings. â'F I could draw as you have drew, Like to jes' swap pens with you! âPicture-drawin' 's my pet vision Of Life-work in Lands Elysian. âPictures is first language we Find hacked out in History. âMost delight we ever took Was in our first Picture-book. â'Thout the funny picture-makers, They'd be lots more undertakers! âStill, as I say, Rhymes and Art 'Smighty hard to tell apart. âSongs and pictures go together Same as birds and summer weather.â So Wess says, and sort o' grins, âArt and Poetry is twins.â THE CHILDREN OF THE CHILDLESS The Children of the Childless!âYoursâand mine.â Yea, though we sit here in the pitying gaze Of fathers and mothers whose fond fingers twine Their children's locks of living gold, and praise With warm, caressing palms, the head of brown, Or crown Of opulent auburn, with its amber floss In all its splendor loosed and jostled down Across The mother-lap at prayer.âYea, even when These sweet petitioners are kissed, and then Are kissed and kissed againâ The pursed mouths lifted with the worldlier prayer That bed and oblivion spare Them yet a little while Beside their envied elders by the glow Of the glad firelight; or wresting, as they go, Some promise for the morrow, to beguile Their long exile Within the wild waste lands of dream and sleep. Nay, nay, not even these most stably real Of children are more loved than our idealâ More tangible to the soul's touch and sight Than theseâour children by Divine birthright. ... Theseâthese of ours, who soothe us, when we weep, With tenderest ministries, Or, flashing into smiling ecstasies, Come dashing through our tearsâay, laughing leap Into our empty arms, in Fate's despite, And nestle to our hearts. O Heaven's delight!â The children of the childlessâeven these!
